Case reference: 2016061097.CaseDesc:
On June 18, 1979, the body of an unidentified male was found in the Detroit River near Riverside Drive and Crawford Avenue in the city of Windsor, Ontario. 
His post-mortem weight was recorded as being 145lbs, however, this measurement may not represent his actual living weight due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy. His appendix was present. 
He is believed to have been in the water for 1 week to six months.

Case reference: 2014002350.CaseDesc: On May 29th, 1990 Pierre Beaudoin left his residence in Hebron, Prince Edward Island. Police later confirmed that Mr. Beaudoin stayed at the Hotel Francis in New Richmond, Quebec and was seen for the last time on May 31, 1990, when he checked out of the hotel. Pierre’s truck and personal belongings were found in a dense, wooded area approximately 45 miles southeast of Route 275 in Balmoral, New Brunswick on August 17th, 1990.

Case reference: 2014006178.CaseDesc: An investigation revealed that nobody had seen or heard from Alex Klym since the mid 1970's. The family had made attempts to locate Alex, but they were unsuccessful and nobody ever reported that he was missing. Inquiries were made with various government agencies in an attempt to find some evidence of him after the mid 1970's. There is no trace of him. The body of Alex Klym has never been recovered. It is not known what happened to Alex, but foul play cannot be ruled out.

Case reference: 2010000299.CaseDesc: On September 3, 2009, Douglas Chong, 62 years of age, called his sister and advised he had attended the Toronto Western Hospital as he had not been feeling well. He advised he had been dehydrated and was sent to Seaton House to recover where he had been for three days and was feeling better. This was the last time anyone has heard from Douglas Chong. He has not retuned to his last known address. Neither Toronto Western Hospital nor Seaton House have any record of Mr. Chong having been there on or about the 3rd of September, 2009. There has been no use of his health or bank cards since September 3, 2009.

Case reference: 2009004999.CaseDesc: At the time of her disappearance, Dawn Carisse was a patient of the North Bay Psychiatric Hospital. She is generally very pleasant though suffers from short term memory loss due to cardiac arrest several years earlier.  Dawn Carisse always spoke of leaving the hospital and going to where she believed her family would be. Her family was in the Kirkland Lake area and then moved to Sudbury. She was aware of both, and her possible destinations were Kirkland Lake or Sudbury. She was last seen on Highway 11 North, in North Bay, Ontario.

Case reference: 2016059266.CaseDesc:
On March 29th, 2008, the body of a male was found under a subway bridge at Bloor and Parliament Streets, Toronto, where he apparently slept often. A beige jacket, black nylon pants, a dark blue knit hat and tan ankle shoes with tan laces were located in close proximity to his body.  He was uncircumcised and his appendix is absent.
He is believed to be a homeless individual and was found by another homeless man who referred to him as "Pops" and "Joe".

Case reference: 2019026482.CaseDesc: Kristofer Couture drove his vehicle from Alberta to the lower mainland in British Columbia to find work and had cut off ties from his family. Kristofer worked construction for a short period of time while living in his vehicle near Maple Ridge, British Columbia. Kristofer also frequented a gym in Burnaby, British Columbia. Kristofer was last seen leaving the Royal Columbian Hospital in New Westminster, British Columbia on January 26, 2019. His unoccupied vehicle was seen the following day parked at the Elk Mountain Trail in Chilliwack, British Columbia. Kristofer was reported missing on May 17, 2019 and his vehicle was found parked at the same location.

Case reference: 2014005452.CaseDesc: Mr. Hopkins departed his cabin on Sunday, November 2, 1975, to go fishing on Lake Athapapuskow. When he failed to return three days later he was reported missing to police by a friend. Soon thereafter, on November 6th, Mr. Hopkins' boat was located overturned banging against rocks. Numerous personal items were found on shore around the boat. Despite intensive boat patrols and dragging operations, Mr. Hopkins has not been found. Foul play is not suspected, and it is assumed that Mr. Hopkins drowned.

Case reference: 2014001684.CaseDesc: On June 30th, 1974 Brent Forsyth was 11 years of age when he went missing while fishing along the Bulkley River by Two Mile Creek in Hazelton BC. Brent was last seen upriver fishing a back-eddy. As a result of Brent's disappearance an extensive search involving community members, search and rescue, RCMP Police Dog Services and RCMP air service entailed. Despite these efforts and continued investigations he has never been located. Police have received new information about Brent and are seeking anyone who might have additional information about Brent's disappearance to come forward.

Case reference: 2013000045.CaseDesc: On September 14, 1964, at approximately 11:00 p.m., Noreen Greenly was seen for the last time leaving her friend’s house. Noreen had told her friend that she was going to wait for the bus at the bus stop across the street. The bus driver was interviewed and he stated that he did not pick her up. A witness had reported seeing a young girl get into a small blue car, and sit close to the driver at approximately the same time and location. The car was described as a 1957 to 1959 Ford Perfect which was in good condition.

Case reference: 2014002831.CaseDesc: On December 26, 1980, Zulfiqar Charania was seen for the last time in Montreal, Quebec. During the time of his disappearance, Zulfiqar lived in Ottawa but was at his sister’s home in Montreal to spend the holidays. When Zulfiqar left Montreal he did so without his suitcase, which was filled with his personal belongings. Zulfiqar had indicated that he intended on travelling to New York in the United States to visit another family member.

Case reference: 2006013199.CaseDesc: Heather Moggy was last seen on June 22, 2002. She may be in the company of John Tucsok who has been affiliated with the "THE ASSEMBLY OF GOD" church. Mr. Tucsok is wanted by the police for offences in Ontario. Heather and John had a joint post office box together in Brantford, Ontario, until September 2003. A letter has been received post marked from Calgary, Alberta. The last contact from Heather Moggy to her family was by telephone, in October 2003, when she indicated that they may be going to Saskatchewan (Moose Jaw).  As of this date, all attempts to locate either subject have failed.

Case reference: 2016065655.CaseDesc:
On May 27, 1978, a female was found floating 1000 feet off the west shore of Fighting Island, Sandwich West Township in the Detroit River. 
Her post-mortem weight was recorded as being 155lbs, however, this measurement may not represent her actual living weight due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy. 
It is estimated that she had been in the water for a couple of days to a couple of weeks.

Case reference: 2014003706.CaseDesc: Albert Crow and a friend attempted to cross Harrop Lake, Manitoba in a canoe despite high winds and the rough water. A second party in another canoe was ahead of Mr. Crow's and observed at one point of the crossing that the canoe was no longer visible. Searches were made of the shoreline and dragging operations of the lake were undertaken at the time without success. On October 12, 1974, the body of Mr. Crow's friend was recovered. His cause of death was later determined to be drowning. Albert Crow is presumed also dead due to drowning.

Case reference: 2013000029.CaseDesc: On November 4, 1991, Montreal Police received a complaint from Mr. Katnick reporting that his daughter Leslie Anne Katnick was missing. Leslie Katnick had been residing in Montreal, Quebec until November 1, 1991, which was the last time she was seen by either friends or family. The investigation revealed that a Leslie Katnick registered into the Halifax YMCA on November 2, 1991, for several nights and returned the key on November 4, 1991. No further information has surfaced with respect to the whereabouts of Leslie Katnick. The circumstances of her disappearance are suspicious and foul play may be involved.

Case reference: 2014004752.CaseDesc: On June 4, 2005 a man attended the Victoria Police Department and reported not seeing Belinda Cameron for over one month.  He told police Belinda had mentioned wanting to visit relatives in Vancouver and Manitoba but did not provide names to police.  This man reported sharing an intimate relationship with Belinda outside of his own marriage.  He said she was not a habitual runaway.  This man denied harming Belinda and through a Polygraph examination was determined to be honest.  The Victoria Police investigated Belinda's disappearance and determined that Belinda suffered from a mental illness, had a drug addiction and may have been a sex trade worker.  The last confirmed sighting of Belinda was at Shoppers Drug Mart at 870 Esquimalt Rd.  She failed to attend thereafter to pick up her daily medication.

Case reference: 2007002999.CaseDesc: Luciano Trinaistich was last seen at his residence on the 24th of July 2007 where he left and indicated that he was going to pick blueberries along Murphy Road near Timmins, Ontario. When he did not return home his wife contacted the Timmins Police Service and reported him missing. A search was conducted by the Timmins Police Service and the Ontario Provincial Police which resulted in locating the missing male's vehicle parked down a sideroad that runs off of Murphy Road. An extensive ground search has been conducted in the vicinity of the recovered vehicle with negative results.

Case reference: 2014005643.CaseDesc: On October 21, 2008, it was reported a boat had capsized in Lake Winnipeg, 15 miles south east of Poplar River between Marchand Point and George Island. The boat left Poplar Point on Oct 20, 2008, to remove buoys from Lake Winnipeg. During the evening, the boat experienced technical difficulties and was unable to continue. Throughout the early morning hours the weather began to worsen, experiencing 10 foot waves, at this time the vessel started to take in water. As a result the boat began to sink. Two of the three passengers were able to make it to Marchand's Point where they were rescued. No foul play is suspected and it is presumed George Donald Everett drowned.

Case reference: 2014004917.CaseDesc: Robert Rudish and Lee Vrba arrived in Island Lake Manitoba on June 11, 1972, to fish. On June 17, RCMP received a report that a canoe was found overturned in the water. The canoe was soon identified as belonging to Mr. Vrba. RCMP Investigators surmised the men went missing on either the Thursday or the Friday. The weather on both days was extreme, with high winds gusting to 30 mph, which caused the lake to be quite rough. Neither of the two men have been located and it is presumed both drowned.

Case reference: 2014001664.CaseDesc: On September 12, 1982, Harold Larcher and his girlfriend set out in separate canoes with their supplies. Both canoes displayed their own leaks. After the river, they saw waves on the lake. The canoes began filling with water from these same waves.  Harold's girlfriends’ canoe sunk but she could see he was still in his canoe as she was struggling to right her own. She was unable to do so, but at one point was able to sit on top of it. Eventually she made her way to shore, however she did not see Harold again.  Numerous personal items belonging to Harold were recovered including his Passport and a life jacket that could have been his.  It is presumed Mr.Larcher drowned.

Case reference: 2012020025.CaseDesc: At about 8:15 pm on May 3, 1983, 16 year old Shelley-Anne Bacsu left a friend’s house in the Sunset Trailer Park to walk the 7 km to her home. Her route took her west on Highway 16 through Hinton, then north on Highway 40. Witnesses saw Shelley-Anne walking westbound along the shoulder of Highway 16 carrying her school books; she was not hitch-hiking. Shelley-Anne was last seen in the area of what was then the western edge of town. A dark colored van was seen in the area around the time Shelley-Anne was walking home, some reports were that it was stopped at the side of the road near where she was last seen. An extensive search for the van and/or its occupants was not successful. Several days after Shelley-Anne was last seen, some of her belongings were found near the Athabasca River not far from the outskirts of Hinton.

Case reference: 2005006699.CaseDesc: On May 22, 2003, an unidentified man believed to be between 50 and 60 years old, was found in the woods off of Humberwood Boulevard, near Highway 427 and Rexdale Blvd., in Toronto. He was found beneath an overturned picnic table that he may have been using for shelter. His post-mortem length was reported to be between 5’0"-5’1" and his weight was 122lbs. Found within the vicinity of his body was a right black leather-type boot, a black sock, a white baseball hat, a green winter jacket, a navy-coloured winter jacket, a black long-sleeved shirt, a black belt and an empty bottle of Listerine mouthwash. It is believed that death occurred within 1-2 days of his discovery.

Case reference: 2014005000.CaseDesc: On August 10, 2004, Mr. Lathlin was reported missing to police by his wife. She indicated to police the last time she saw Mr. Lathlin was on June 14th at which time he was leaving for Winnipeg from The Pas for a medical appointment on the 15th. He did not take any clothing and only took personal grooming items. Mr. Lathlin later called advising his wife he would be staying in Winnipeg as he had another appointment on Thursday. He again called his wife on Saturday morning asking for money. His wife sent the money as requested, however by Tuesday it was not claimed and it was returned to her. Mr. Lathlin has a history of living on the streets and has ties to Edmonton where he spent years on the street there. He also has various medical concerns. It is believed that Mr. Lathlin is likely in Winnipeg of his own volition. Mr. Lathlin's whereabouts remain unknown.

PersonsData.Name: LATHLIN, Louis Charles

Case reference: 2014003678.CaseDesc: On June 21, 1960, Donald McKillop's wife reported him missing to the Police. The last time she spoke to her husband was on June 19. She was working away from the home and returned on the June 20 to find her husband away.   Mr. McKillop's wife indicated to police she had spoken to her husband and he had not indicated he was leaving for any reason. Donald McKillop left the home without his wallet, there was no clothing missing and all his carpentry tools were present. Inquiries with family and friends revealed nothing else. Mr. McKillop had no history of mental disorder or suicidal tendencies.  There is no indication of foul play in his disappearance.

Case reference: 2014002108.CaseDesc: Craig Waldum along with 7 others were on a canoeing expedition along the Nelson River. Craig was one of two guides on the expedition. On August 18, 1978, three members of the expedition were on shore guiding in a canoe. The remaining 5 members including Craig remained in the canoe. As these individuals labored to guide the canoe to shore, the rope was given some slack. This caused the bow of the canoe to turn out into the current, which in turn caused the canoe to tip. The individuals on shore were unable to hold onto the rope due to the strength of the current and the canoe was carried downstream. Craig hung onto the canoe for a couple hours then was seen letting go. He slipped under the water and did not resurface. Mr. Waldum's remains have not been recovered and foul play is not suspected in this matter.

PersonsData.Name: WALDUM, Craig Edward

Case reference: 2015060160.CaseDesc: On May 27, 1970, a male was found floating in the water at the foot of Seguins Boat House in Rockcliffe, Ottawa. He has partially balding, grey hair. His post-mortem weight was recorded as being 158 lbs and his length was measured at 5'8", however, these measurements may not represent his actual living weight and height due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy. Several anterior and posterior teeth were missing in the upper and lower jaw. He had 1 cent and a pack of matches in his pocket. It is believed that he had been in the water for up to 48 hours prior to recovery.

Case reference: 2005004799.CaseDesc: On February 17, 1991, an unidentified man was found floating in Lake Ontario, near 'Captain John's Boat Restaurant' on Queens Quay, west of Yonge Street near the Harbour Castle Hotel. His post-mortem weight was recorded as being 166 lbs, however, this may not represent his actual living weight due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy. His skin was brown, perhaps suggesting a Middle Eastern, East Indian or North African ethnic affiliation. He had a wide nose and long slim fingers. His appendix was present and he was circumcised.

Case reference: 2014003903.CaseDesc: Anthony Kootenay walked away from the Algar Tower fire camp 73 kilometres south of Fort McMurray, Alberta on July 13, 1985 at approximately 3:00 am. In the previous days he was described by colleagues as suffering from mental health issues related to alcohol abuse. It is believed he may have attempted to hitch-hike from the area as a passing motorist spotted someone matching his description. An extensive search by land and helicopter was conducted, however Anthony was not located. Two unconfirmed sightings occurred at the Grand Hotel in Edmonton, AB on December 23, 1985 and January 16, 1986. There have been no sightings since that time.

Case reference: 2014001413.CaseDesc: Captain Charles David Tillsley, Warrant Officer Tyrus Cobb, Sergeant Major James Mackey and fourth companion departed Fort Churchill for a weekend fishing trip on the Churchill River. They were last seen loading their gear into a boat around 1:00 pm at the Churchill Dock. They were expected back on Sunday September 20th, 1959 but failed to return. The Fort Churchill Military authorities commenced a search with the aid of helicopters and aircraft. On September 21st, the two boats the men used were located, both were swamped and undamaged. Numerous items were found and were identified as belonging to the four men. Extensive land and water searches were conducted.

Case reference: 2009002399.CaseDesc: On Friday, April 21, 1972, Francis Harris went to a medical appointment with her husband in Peterborough. On the way home to Apsley, they stopped in Lakefield and she may have gone to the post office and the bank. They arrived home around 11:00 a.m. and ate lunch. Her husband went to work from approximately 1:00 p.m. to 5:05 p.m.  When their son returned home from school at about 3:40 p.m., Mrs. Harris was not home.  She has not been seen or heard from since.

Case reference: 2014004809.CaseDesc: Jeffrey Peterson was reported missing on August 7, 2006, by a family member.  Investigators were advised that Mr. Peterson's vehicle was not taken and that he does not have a history of leaving without first communicating with them. It was later determined that Mr. Peterson was last seen by a neighbor, close to his residence in Manitou, Manitoba, on the afternoon of August 5, 2006.  Numerous searches were conducted of Manitou and the surrounding area, none of which were successful.

Case reference: 2014004857.CaseDesc: On September 21, 1992, David Neufeld, Peter Bentzen and Kenneth Vaughan were seen for the last time in Toronto, Ontario. The three men had been associating with each other as “runners” in order to smuggle cigarettes into Canada from the United States by means of a boat. David’s vehicle and boat trailer were located at Ashbridges Bay, Toronto. The aging boat that was borrowed from a friend has never been recovered and the three men have not been seen or heard from since.

Case reference: 2014004580.CaseDesc: On the morning of the 23rd of July 1991, a group of 8 individuals left Igloolik NU. heading to Hall Beach, NU.  The group travelled using a 24 feet freighter canoe powered by a 30 hp outboard.  It was a stormy day with heavy rain.  Approximately 15 miles North of Hall Beach, the canoe hit ice, filled with water and capsized.  Only one occupant made it back to shore.

Case reference: 2005007499.CaseDesc: On August 7, 1985, an unidentified man, believed to be between the ages of 50-60 years, was recovered from the Niagara River near the Maid of the Mist boarding dock. His post-mortem weight was recorded as 127.5lbs. His post-mortem length was measured at 5'3''-5'4''; however, due to traumatic injury this may not accurately represent his actual living height. He was recovered without clothing or personal effects. It is not known how long he had been in the water. A man, similarly described, was seen jumping over the Niagara Falls 5 days prior to the date that this unidentified man was recovered.

Case reference: 2014005499.CaseDesc: During the early morning hours of Friday, October 1st, 2010, Janice Cher Desjarlais and her boyfriend crawled into a dumpster located behind The Center of Hope on Franklin Avenue in Fort McMurray. Janice's boyfriend advised that he left at approximately 7:30 a.m. to go to McDonald’s restaurant. When he returned at around 8:30 a.m., Janice was gone. When he was unable to find her, he suspected that the dumpster may have been emptied during his absence. On October 3rd, video surveillance of the area confirmed that the dumpster had been picked up at 8:22 a.m. on October 1st. It also showed the departure of Janice's boyfriend, but no one else entering or leaving the dumpster. On October 5th, a major excavation of the landfill was started, but by the time the search was completed on October 14th, Janice had not been located.

Case reference: 2011000499.CaseDesc: In August 1996, Bruce Berthelot left his family residence in Leamington, Ontario. M. Berthelot indicated that he was going away for a little while and asked his mother for $1000. He had been unemployed for several months and was dealing with some health issues. Prior to leaving he telephoned his friends in Manitoba a number of times. His family believes that he was headed to Western Canada. He has lived in Manitoba in the past. Mr. Berthelot is a skilled carpenter, and enjoys fishing and boating.  He has had no contact with any members of his family or friends since leaving.

Case reference: 2005000299.CaseDesc: On August 28, 2005, the remains of a female were found in a wooded location at an MTO picnic area on Highway #7 west of Rockwood, Ontario. It is believed the female had been dragged a short distance into the woods, beside the picnic area and had been there for approximately a month before being discovered. A "Woods" sleeping bag had been placed over top of the deceased, covering her. No personal jewelry or identification was found with the deceased. The clothing that she wore was found to have been purchased in the Montreal area. Investigators believe the circumstances of her death are suspicious and consider this foul play.

Case reference: 2005006499.CaseDesc:
On December 17, 1977, the remains of an unidentified man were found on the shore of Lake Ontario near Long Branch Park, Toronto. Anthropological analysis suggests that he may be Hispanic. 
His post-mortem weight was recorded as being 140lbs, however, this measurement may not represent his actual living weight due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy.
It is believed that he had been dead for at least one year prior to his discovery.

Case reference: 2014003250.CaseDesc: On November 1, 1974, four people left the Whitedog Indian Reserve, Ontario in a 14' Lund boat and were heading for Pointe du Bois, Manitoba. Their intention was to go to Pointe du Bois to pick up supplies and then return to Whitedog. On November 5, 1974, these individuals were reported missing as they had never returned to Whitedog.  It is believed that the boat overturned and everyone drowned. Two bodies were recovered, and the cause of death was determined to be drowning. Searches were conducted by boat and by air but the bodies of Paul Scott and Richard Petawanahqueb were never recovered.  Mr. Scott and Mr. Petawanahqueb are presumed dead due to drowning. No foul play is suspected.

Case reference: 2012020018.CaseDesc: Sahil Sharma has been missing from the Newton area of Surrey, B.C. since November 13, 2008.  On the day Sahil disappeared, he had attended to Kwantlen University in Surrey, B.C. to pay for his upcoming semester to study Information Technology.  Sahil did not have any known drug or alcohol addictions and no known mental health issues.  Sahil's disappearance is highly out of character and all avenues of investigation have not provided any information on his whereabouts.

Case reference: 2014007307.CaseDesc: On the 28th of May, 1987, a small shed was moved and a body of what appeared to be a full term infant was found. It had been wrapped in two towels and placed under the shed. Examination of the body was done by the University Of Saskatchewan Department Of Archaeology. It was determined the body was that of a full or part North American Indian and had been there from one to three years. The sex of the infant could not be determined. This case is being investigated by the Office of the Chief Coroner and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

Case reference: 2014003215.CaseDesc: On June 24, 1972, a group of seven people, including Hank Ethier, were fishing on the Burntwood River. Late in the day the group and their two boats went to shore for supper. One group, which included Hank, left the shore. They were however unable to get their boat started and as a result they began to drift backwards towards the rapids. This group called for help and the other boat went to their aid. Hank jumped from his boat and swam to the second one. Once they reached the disabled boat everyone was told to get in. Both boats encountered the rapids. It is assumed Hank drowned as a result of the mishap.

Case reference: 2012020085.CaseDesc: Benjamin Entz was born and raised on the Waldeck Hutterite Colony near Waldeck, SK and resided there up until the time he went missing. He was described by friends and family as being a loner who kept to himself. Mr. Entz left the colony on the evening of 2011-09-18 at which time he was seen driving away on a tractor which was later recovered the following day. The investigation/search for Mr. Entz has involved numerous witness interviews, air and ground searches, and media releases, however he has yet to be located.

Case reference: 2014001853.CaseDesc: On May 19, 1958, Clifford McKell and a friend were last seen having supper and told friends they were going out in the canoe. Neither of the men were considered experienced paddlers. No one witnessed the men leaving in the canoe. The following day they were reported missing by their employer when they failed to report to work. Police commenced an investigation and an air search found the overturned canoe. Paddles and safety cushions were also located. A witness who saw two men in a canoe around 8:30 pm indicated they were headed in a southerly direction and the lake was quite rough at the time. It is presumed Mr. McKell drowned.

Case reference: 2009000199.CaseDesc: On October 17, 1996, Alf Joergensen left his residence to go on a business trip to London, England. Mr. Joergensen told his wife he would be returning on either October 22nd or 23rd. He indicated he was meeting a business associate in London, however it was later confirmed there were no scheduled  business meetings with this particular individual, who hadn't seen Mr. Joergensen since the previous year. Mr. Joergensen flew to England on October 17, 1996 and was confirmed to have flown into Toronto airport on October 19, 1996, via British Airways. He has not been seen nor heard from since this date and his family and police are concerned for his safety and well-being.

Case reference: 2006003399.CaseDesc: On November 2, 2001, this male, was found in a sewer at 470 Lansdowne Avenue in Toronto. His ancestry is Caucasian, possibly Egyptian or mixed African/Caucasian. He had previous surgery of his left forearm, which had involved the implant of surgical plates. The numbers visible on the surgical plates could not be traced to a specific individual, however, it was determined that the lot was released some time after May 25, 1994. A MacDonald’s name tag with the name "Raymond" was found in the sewer, which may or may not be related to this individual.

Case reference: 2014001801.CaseDesc: On July 17, 1992, Marshall Holmes wandered into the bush near Vassar, Manitoba and has not been seen since. Mr. Holmes was 73 years old at the time and was described as a recluse and a hermit. Mr. Holmes had gone missing in the past and had returned on his own accord. He enjoyed being in the bush and liked to sleep in the long grass. The last time he went missing he was gone for 3 days and came out of the bush when he became hungry. Extensive searches were done by land, air and with the assistance of a police dog. Marshall Holmes has never been located.

Case reference: 2016065869.CaseDesc: On April 11, 1976, the decomposed remains of a male individual were recovered from the water in Port Arthur Marina in the Thunder Bay Harbour. His post-mortem weight was recorded as being 170-180 lbs, however, this may not represent his actual living weight due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy. His pockets contained a red handkerchief, pipe for smoking, book of matches and a broken pencil. It is believed that he had been in the water since the fall of 1975.

Case reference: 2016012810.CaseDesc: On March 12th, 2016 shortly after midnight, Denny Poole and a friend left Dawson Creek with the intent of heading to Fort St John. It is unknown if they intended to walk, hitchhike, or had other means to get there. The duo became disoriented and ended up wandering the highway and back roads for over 20 hours. It was learned that neither of them was prepared to be out for this period of time. At some point, Denny and his friend had a difference of opinion on whether they should continue on their journey or not, and the two ended up separating. The last confirmed sighting of Denny was just south of the Kiskatinaw Bridge on Highway 97. Denny has some disabilities and it is recommended that he be under adult supervision.

Case reference: 2012020138.CaseDesc: The 18 month old Yohanna went missing after the mother entrusted the custody of her daughter to her boyfriend while she was out of town for a few days. They all lived in the Saint Laurent area in Montreal. Upon her return to Montreal, the mother was told that her baby was in Washington with the boyfriend’s mother. She went to the United States to find her daughter, but could not locate her. Returning to Quebec, the mother alerted the police of her child’s disappearance. The boyfriend claimed then that the child drowned in the bathtub during the mother’s absence and that she had been buried before the mother’s return. He was questioned and then released due to lack of evidence.

Case reference: 2014002370.CaseDesc: On June 16, 1997, at approximately 4:30 pm Kelvin Zdarski and two friends left Dauphin, Manitoba and headed for a cabin near Waterhen, Manitoba. Over the course of the evening there was an argument between the men. Kelvin left the cabin and never returned. The men looked for him on their way back to Dauphin and did not see him. A man matching Kelvin's description was seen walking on the road at 7:30 am on the 17th of June. An extensive search by land, air and water proved negative. Kelvin did not take his wallet, money or any identification to the cabin and had no means of transportation. Mr. Zdarski has not been seen or heard from again.

Case reference: 2014006235.CaseDesc: A lake freighter capsized in a violent storm on Lake Winnipeg, just north of Hecla Island, Manitoba. The vessel carried nine crew members and one passenger. There was only one survivor who managed to float on a piece of the wreckage to safety. All of the bodies of the remaining occupants were recovered with the exception of Allan Clemens and Tache Everett who were never located. Autopsies confirmed that the causes of death for those recovered were either drowning or death due to exposure in the cold water. Mr. Clemens and Mr. Everett are presumed dead due to drowning.

Case reference: 2014006028.CaseDesc: On January 18th, 2013, the Teton family checked into the New Otani Inn, located in Yokohama, Japan.  This was to be the final destination before returning to Canada.  While Henrik was in the shower, his wife Chieko and 1 year old son Takaya vanished. Henrik sought the assistance of police in Yokohama and the Canadian Embassy, to no avail. Shortly thereafter, Henrik attended 52 Division to report the incident and his subsequent attempt to locate his family. Toronto Police requested the assistance of Japanese police to confirm Chieko’s and Takaya’s well-being and Chieko’s intentions.  It was confirmed that both are in good health and that Chieko does not wish her whereabouts be disclosed.

Case reference: 2014004487.CaseDesc: On June 3, 2003, at approximately 9:00 a.m. a fisherman and his helper, Phillip McKay, left Berens River Manitoba to retrieve their commercial fishing nets from Sandy Bar Bay. Upon arrival, one of the nets got caught in the propeller of the boat motor, pulling the boat down. Shortly thereafter, 2 large waves capsized the boat and both men were thrown into the water. Both men were wearing oilers, making it difficult to swim. The fisherman survived and was treated for shock and hypothermia. The body of his helper, Phillip McKay was never located.  Phillip McKay is presumed dead due to drowning.

Case reference: 2013000141.CaseDesc: Brandyn Dirienzo was last seen on the evening of October 4, 2006, entering an apartment building in Chilliwack, B.C. Brandyn was living a high risk lifestyle and foul play is heavily suspected. The police investigation into the disappearance of Brandyn is focussed on identifying those who have directly caused Brandyn's disappearance and/or death. Brandyn is the father of two young children and his family is deeply affected by his disappearance.

Case reference: 2014004819.CaseDesc: Reginald Andrew FLETT (known as Reggie) was last seen walking around downtown Thompson, Manitoba shortly before his disappearance on either September 16th or 17th, 2007. FLETT had also been spotted earlier near both the Thompson Walmart and the Extra Foods. He was reported as missing by a family member on September 19, 2006.   Shortly thereafter, family members from Split Lake, Manitoba conducted searches around both Split Lake and Thompson, both of which failed to uncover any trace of FLETT. Thereafter, missing persons posters were distributed throughout Thompson. Although FLETT's whereabouts remain unknown, the investigation is ongoing.

Case reference: 2014002368.CaseDesc: On June 11th, 1969, at approximately 5:50 PM, the Happy Valley-Goose Bay RCMP received a report of an empty boat drifting in Lake Melville, in the vicinity of North West Point, North West River, NL.  Police attended and learned that this empty boat belonged to Lawrence Alton Oliver, who had been reported to have departed his residence earlier in the morning to go seal hunting.  It is believed that Mr. Oliver fell overboard while hunting and drowned.  The body of Mr. Oliver has never been located.

Case reference: 2009001399.CaseDesc: Calvin Vanness was last seen on March 26, 2008 at approximately 2:30 PM in the Quinte Mall parking lot in Belleville, Ontario. He last spoke to his family to make plans to meet later that day. When he failed to meet them, his family attempted to locate him, then reported him missing on March 31, 2008. His car was located on April 1, 2008 at the Highway 38 car park in Kingston, Ontario. He was known to carry large sums of money and some cannabis. Mr. Vanness has not accessed any of his bank accounts since his disappearance.

Case reference: 2005006899.CaseDesc: On July 16, 1980, the skeletal remains of an unidentified man were found in a bush area on the east side of the 11th Concession, 1km north of Steeles Avenue in Markham. This man is believed to be between the ages of 30 to 50 years. His living height is estimated to be between 5'1"-5'5". Dark staining of his posterior teeth suggest that he may have been a smoker. Found in the vicinity of the remains were some clothing and effects, which may or may not be associated with the deceased. The clothing found included a pair of "Brittania" women's jeans (waist 30 inches, inseam 29 inches); a pair of white, ribbed socks; and a pair of red and pink high-heeled shoes. A compact containing powder and mirror was also found nearby. This man was believed to have been dead for 6 months to five years.

Case reference: 2012020055.CaseDesc:
The body of an Asian male was discovered by cleaning staff at the Northbrook Inn in Grand Rapids, Manitoba.  The individual had checked in at 15:30h after arriving on the bus from Winnipeg.  At 18:00h cleaning staff entered the room to find the occupant deceased in a chair.
It was learned that the subject checked into the hotel under the name "CHERON, Deoung".  A small black bag containing herbal medication was located in the room, which after translation from Korean revealed the prescription was issued to "PARK, Seng Dae"(variation of spelling PARK, Sang Dae).  It should be noted that the bus ticket-stub was located with the deceased identified "DUNG" as the individual who purchased the ticket.
Numerous checks were made with variety of agencies in an attempt to determine the man's identity.  It is believed he may be of Korean or Chinese decent.

Case reference: 2006001699.CaseDesc:
On July 27, 1992, the body of a male, believed to be Caucasian, was found in the Toronto Harbour of Lake Ontario. His post-mortem weight was recorded as being 160lbs, however, this measurement may not represent his actual living weight due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy.
His upper right central incisor had a root canal treatment and there was a metallic restoration at its root end. There were several other sites of root canal treatment.
His appendix was present and he was uncircumcised.

Case reference: 2010004199.CaseDesc: Kalon Purvis had been living and working in the Minden area since early May 2008.  He had been involved in a car accident on June 19, 2008 resulting in him needing to use a rental car.  The small red rental car was returned sometime in July.  Mr. Purvis was last seen in July 2008 when he was dropped off in the area of the Home Hardware store in Minden to meet someone he was going to do some work for, for two weeks.  Mr. Purvis would have had a large male dog (Rottweiler) named Magnum with him around the time of his disappearance.

Case reference: 2014001837.CaseDesc: On September 29, 1979 at approximately 8:30 a.m. seven men departed from Anama Bay, Manitoba on a fishing trip. The men departed as a group in three separate boats and were heading for Warpath. At approximately 7:30 p.m. that same day, the occupants of the first boat reported to the RCMP that the other two boats were missing. They described the waves as being three to four feet high and they could not see the tree line from where they were. They lost sight of the other two boats and fired shotgun shots into the air hoping for a response. No response was received. Extensive patrols by air, boat and land were made in an attempt to locate the remaining five men. The bodies of Fredrick Ursu and Jerry Hudy were never recovered. Mr. Ursu and Mr. Hudy are presumed dead due to drowning.

Case reference: 2013000102.CaseDesc: On September 25, 1981 at approximately 7:30 p.m., Lawrence (Larry) Bennett left Princess Harbour, Manitoba in his boat heading for Matheson Island. Case reference: 2006029199.CaseDesc: On October 27, 2006, a female was found in a field near the South Service Road and Holt Road near the Darlington Nuclear Plant in Bowmanville, Ontario. She may have been anemic, but a doctor may or may not have diagnosed this condition. Near the body there was a ring, size 9.5, that has a red garnet in the middle with a diamond on either side. The ring is stamped "Burns" on the inside and is believed to have been sold through Burns Jeweler in Oshawa, Ontario. A heart, a ribbon and a multi coloured "Blue Rodeo" brand t-shirt with a hood were also found in the vicinity of the remains and may or may not belong to her.

Case reference: 2014005742.CaseDesc: Philip Mark Oslizlok was reported missing by his family in early 2010. He was last seen on September 2, 2009 when he went to the Vancouver Police Department to receive an employment record clearance. Mr. Oslizlok last contacted his family via email on November 20, 2009 to inform them that he had gotten a job on a cruise line and would not be returning home for Christmas. There are no records of employment for Philip at any of the cruise lines. He has not been seen or heard from since.

Case reference: 2008000799.CaseDesc: On August 26th, 1986 Terry FIELD and Linda BLACKWELL left Lost Nation Airport, east of Cleveland, Ohio en route to Brantford Municipal Airport, Brantford, Ontario.  The plane was 18 minutes into its flight when the pilot communicated with Cleveland Air Traffic Control that they were encountering severe turbulence.  They requested new vectors to fly. The pilot was advised to turn west, then Air Traffic Control lost radio and radar contact with the plane. Debris from the plane was located on August 27, 1986 in Lake Erie, approximately 32 nautical miles south of the St.Thomas Airport. Debris was drifting in a southeast direction and was recovered approximately 1-3 nautical miles on the Canadian side of the international boundary line in Lake Erie. Debris was identified by Bud FIELD,  brother of Terry FIELD, as having come from the missing aircraft.

Case reference: 2013000026.CaseDesc: John Antic's wife spoke with him at 11:00 a.m. on November 5, 2012 at a local Burlington mall. Mr. Antic left the mall wearing appropriate clothing for the weather. At approximately 7:30 p.m., Mrs. Antic received a phone call from a woman on behalf of Mr. Antic. She could hear her husband in the background saying he was eating dinner at a restaurant in Niagara Falls, Ontario. Mr. Antic's presence at the restaurant was confirmed. It is believed that he was on foot, and is familiar with public transportation. Mr. Antic has had no contact with his family or banking institutions since. There were no pre-existing medical, domestic or mental health issues.

Case reference: 2016061964.CaseDesc: On December 26, 1976, an unidentified Caucasian man, believed to be between the ages of 55 to 60 years old, was found in an abandoned blue van near 21 Blackburn Avenue, Toronto. He was malnourished, very dirty and heavily infested with lice. Locals knew him to live under the bridge at the foot of Blackburn Ave for about 15 years and he was known to local children as old Billy. He was circumcised. His feet showed frostbite which had become infected.

Case reference: 2014002147.CaseDesc: On September 22nd, 1981 Churchill RCMP received a call from Mrs. Esmoil advising her two sons, and two friends were late on returning from a canoe trip. On August 18th, 1981, Brian Dean Esmoil, his brother, and two friends headed out on an extended canoe trip from Leaf Rapids to Churchill. Numerous items, belonging to the men were found on shore. The bodies of three of the four travelers were recovered on the Churchilll River and death was due to drowning. The body of Brian Esmoil has never been recovered and it is presumed he drowned.

Case reference: 2017060723.CaseDesc: On October 9, 2017, Amber Barlow was last seen in the area of 107 Street and 152 Avenue, Edmonton. Early the following morning, Amber made a post on social media, which she constantly used to communicate with family and friends. Her social media account had no further activity after this time. It is unknown when she left her residence, what she was last wearing or how she may have left. Amber did not have access to a vehicle and would typically use public transit to get around. She lived a high risk lifestyle and seemed despondent on the night she was last seen.

Case reference: 2014001521.CaseDesc: On November 3, 1972, a helicopter carrying a pilot and three passengers went missing in Lake Winnipeg. The helicopter left Thompson, Manitoba at 3:20 p.m. and was heading for Winnipeg after stopping at a number of communities. The helicopter landed at Warren's Landing at approximately 5:20 p.m., and left for Winnipeg. The pilot reported that the weather was poor and he estimated his arrival in Winnipeg at 8:00 p.m. At 5:50 p.m. there was radio contact with the pilot where he stated that he was over Poplar River. This was the last radio contact with this helicopter. The Canadian Air Search and Rescue, private aircraft and police aircraft searched until November 17, 1972 when the search was suspended until the spring of 1973. Nathan Kryger and Ian Fraser are presumed dead as a result of the helicopter crash. Foul play is not suspected.

Case reference: 2013000024.CaseDesc: Susan Dawson was living with, and working for, Terry Murphy for approximately 3 weeks prior to her disappearance. She was last seen in the late hours of November 12, 1985 at a gathering at Terry's house. On November 13, a blue car was seen in Terry's yard. On November 14, at approximately 11:55 a.m., a massive explosion occurred at Terry's residence. Terry's remains were found in the debris but there was no indication that Susan was in the house at the time of the explosion. Investigators suspect foul play, and that Terry had some involvement with Susan's disappearance.

Case reference: 2014006556.CaseDesc: On the 23rd of July, 2006, Preston WALDNER was swimming at Paradise Beach, South Saskatchewan River, when he and another fellow were attempting to swim across the river. The boys got part way across when they ran into trouble due to the very strong current of the river. The one fellow was pulled from the river and survived, however Mr. WALDNER was seen going under and he never resurfaced. A search was conducted but Mr. WALDNER has not been located.

Case reference: 2016030649.CaseDesc: Kean Luo was originally from Malaysia, but had moved to the United States to attend school and begin his career. On March 2, 2016 Mr. Luo moved to Winnipeg, Manitoba for work. Friends and family began to worry about Mr. Luo as they were unable to reach him for an extended period of time. However, on April 2, 2016, police spoke with Mr. Luo at a local hotel. Mr. Luo said that he was not feeling suicidal, but was feeling stressed and missing his family. He was last seen on April 2, 2016 on the Sergeant Thomas Cooper bridge with his vehicle parked on the shoulder of the highway. All cell phone and bank activity have ceased.

Case reference: 2014001528.CaseDesc: On June 17, 1983, Herbert Keam stayed over at a friends house in Poplar River. Herbert asked his friend to walk with him to Norway House. His friend said no, but they walked together to Herbert's sister's house where they parted ways. Mr. Keam's sister indicated she saw Herbert that morning. He changed his clothing and left the residence without indicating what his plans were. Mr.Keam was reported missing on June 20, by his sister. Police later determined that Herbert was attempting to walk (112km's) to Norway House through the bush, however he started out in the wrong direction. The ground search utilized a police dog and various articles of clothing belonging to Herbert were found. The weather at this time was hot and muggy. Mr. Keam has not been located and his whereabouts remain unknown.

Case reference: 2016026481.CaseDesc:
On October 2, 1970, the remains of a Caucasian male were found along Wellington County Road, near Guelph/Cambridge, Ontario. He had severe osteoarthritis in his lumbar area, which may have been painful. Found in close proximity were a yellow carpenter's pencil and a tin spectacle case. 9 various buttons were found: 1 overcoat button, 1 trouser button, 3 shirt buttons, 4 underwear buttons; and some pieces of fabric that may be from a white shirt and white socks were also recovered. 
He is believed to have been deceased for approximately 20 years.

Case reference: 2005004599.CaseDesc: On August 22, 1996, an unidentified man, believed to be Caucasian was recovered from the Sir Adam Beck Dam in the Niagara River. His post-mortem weight was recorded as being 145 lbs and his length was measured at 5'10" to 5’11”, however, these measurements may not represent his actual living weight and height due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy. He has evidence of heart disease and may have had heart problems in the past. It is estimated that he had been in the water for a few days up to two weeks prior to discovery. Biogeographic Ancestry testing predicts that this unidentified male is of European ancestry.

On July 15, 1992, the remains of an adult male, were found in the basement apartment of an abandoned residential building on 1348 Yonge Street in Toronto.

Case reference: 2014005278.CaseDesc: On July 14, 2009, Yashpal Mehay left his residence in Surrey BC, and was scheduled to travel to Clinton BC, where he co-owned and operated a Petro Canada Gas Station with family. Yashpal Mehay was last seen at the Costco in Abbotsford BC, at 1450 hours on July 14, 2009, where he purchased tobacco, food and gas. Mr. Mehay failed to arrive at his destination in Clinton BC, and there has been no communication with the family. He was very familiar with this route as he travelled it every other week. The Surrey RCMP has conducted extensive searches along the travelled route with negative results.

Case reference: 2016066676.CaseDesc:
Between August 6th and August 13th, 1969, several body parts, believed to belong to the same male individual, were recovered from the water around the Ontario Hydro Forebay, Niagara Falls.
His eyes are brown with very prominent arcus senilis (ring-shaped grayish-white deposit near the peripheral edge of the cornea). His appendix and gall bladder are present. This individual was estimated to have been in the water for at least a few days to a week prior to recovery.

Case reference: 2014004918.CaseDesc: On September 15th, 1993, three men were en route to Wuskwatim Lake via the Burntwood River intending to engage in commercial fishing. The men departed Nelson House, according to the only survivor they hit a rock and the motor quit. The boat was not equipped with a starter and the men were unable to restart the boat prior to going through the rapids.   Despite an intensive land, water and air search the bodies of Mr. Moose and Mr. Spence were never recovered.

Case reference: 2014003868.CaseDesc: On Sunday, April 18, 1976, at approximately 12:00 pm, Gary Michael Pinkney departed his residence in Fort Churchill, Manitoba on his snowmobile. He was destined for the Hudson Bay and had planned to return home that same evening. On April 19, 1976, at approximately 8:00 am, Helen Pinkney contacted the Churchill RCMP Detachment and reported that her husband had not yet returned home. Extensive searches were done of the area by land and by air for several days with negative results.   The remains of Mr. Pinkney have not been located and given his intended route, it is presumed that he drowned.

Case reference: 2016068138.CaseDesc: On April 3, 1985, a male was recovered from the Detroit River near Cooper's Marina in the township of Anderdon, County Essex, 5 km north of Amherstburg. His post-mortem weight was recorded as being 190-200lbs, however, these measurements may not represent his actual living weight due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy. He has no obvious scars or tattoos and is uncircumcised. Police believe that this individual is American, based on the clothing labels. It is thought that he had been in the water for as long as two months.

Case reference: 2005007599.CaseDesc: On May 21, 1986, a Caucasian male was found in the Niagara River, near the Whirlpool. He was estimated to be between 50-70 years old. His post-mortem weight was recorded as being 127 lbs and his length was measured at 5’6”, however, these measurements may not represent his actual living weight and height due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy. He had large earlobes. This male also had his appendix and was uncircumcised. He is thought to have been in the water for a few days to a few weeks.

Case reference: 2014004667.CaseDesc: The Gypsumville RCMP detachment received a report that an aircraft was in distress over Lake Winnipeg near Reindeer Island. The aircraft, a single engine Cherokee 140, had three people on board; the pilot and two passengers. The pilot had indicated that the engine had seized and that he was trying to make it to Reindeer Island. He then stated that he was going down in to the water. Two RCMP Twin Otters and an Air Search and Rescue Hercules conducted a search by air. It was not possible to search the lake by boat as there was too much ice on the lake. All three are presumed dead due to drowning or from the impact of the crash.

Case reference: 2009000299.CaseDesc: On November 5, 1989 at approximately 5:30 pm, Mr. George Giles and a friend left Mr. Giles' cottage on Fox Island in Lake Simcoe enroute to a marina at Island Grove.  Weather conditions were very poor at the time and the boat eventually capsized some distance from shore, after taking on water. His friend managed to swim back to Fox Island but Mr. Giles was not able to make it to shore, due to the treacherous weather and water conditions. On November 20th, 1989 the boat was discovered stranded on a sandbank near Joyland Beach in Orillia. Mr. Giles' body has never been recovered.

Case reference: 2006001299.CaseDesc:
On July 6, 1991, the body of an adult male was recovered from Lake Ontario near the east end of Harbour Square Park, at the foot of Bay Street.
His post-mortem weight was recorded as being in between 169-178lbs, however, this measurement may not represent his actual living weight due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy. He is described as having a muscular build. 

He is believed to have been in the water for a few days to a couple of weeks prior to his discovery.

Case reference: 2013000120.CaseDesc: Lisa Marie Young was last seen in the early morning hours of June 30, 2002.  She went to a local bar, and met some male acquaintances after the bar closed. She and her acquaintances accepted a ride from another man whom they had just met.  Lisa Marie was last seen with the man in the vehicle, heading to get some food.  Her friends and family have not heard from her since, which is completely out of character. Due to the nature of this investigation, Nanaimo RCMP Serious Crime Unit requests that anyone with information contact them directly.

Case reference: 2012020065.CaseDesc: On December 3, 1979, Shane Olecka was reported missing to the Beausejour RCMP. Shane was last seen leaving his home the previous day to go rabbit hunting. He was an experienced woodsman and there was no logical reason for him to be overdue. The weather conditions worsened to 'blizzard-like' on December 3rd and made the search efforts very difficult. The police conducted ground searches with the assistances of a police dog, members from the Canadian Forces base and local volunteers. The ground search was terminated on December 8th due to inclement weather.

Case reference: 2014003138.CaseDesc: On October 17, 1981, John Sanderson was with some friends in Berens River, Manitoba.  He left in a 22' boat heading for Jackhead, Manitoba.  Friends tried to stop him from leaving due to the high winds but he left anyway. On October 19, 1981, the boat that he had taken was found upside down and partly submerged near the shore of Pigeon Point. Gas cans that had been in the boat were also located.  Searches were done by air and water but the body of John was never found. It is presumed that Mr. Sanderson drowned.

Case reference: 2016068714.CaseDesc: On June 26, 1967, the remains of a female were recovered from the Niagara River. Her post-mortem length was measured at 5’1”-5’2”, however, this measurement may not represent her actual living height due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy. Her appendix was present. The body is believed to have been in the water for some months to years prior to recovery.

Case reference: 2016061153.CaseDesc: On April 20, 1996, a male was found on the shores of the Detroit River in the 800 block of Front Road North, Amherstburg. His post-mortem weight was recorded as being 200 lbs, however, this measurement may not represent his actual living weight due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy. He is described as balding, however, due to the length of time spent in the water, it is possible that his hair was lost after death giving the appearance of male pattern baldness. He is uncircumcised. His appendix is present. Changes to his heart suggest that he had high blood pressure and may have been treated for this. It is believed that he was in the water for days to weeks prior to his discovery.

Case reference: 2008006899.CaseDesc: On November 2, 1966, Mr. Wynacht and two of his friends went hunting North of Sudbury along hydro pole lines, 20 miles north of Gauthiers corners on hwy 69, Kitchener Township. As a snow storm picked up, the hunters got separated along the pole lines, and Mr. Wynacht vanished. On the morning of Saturday November 5, 1966, a police cruiser led the search of the area with 35 citizens and two aircrafts. The search was completed on November 15, 1966, with negative results and no clue as to his disappearance had been uncovered.

PersonsData.Name: WYNACHT, Donald Edward

Case reference: 2014003615.CaseDesc: On September 26th, 1970, Mr. Claus and his friend were reported missing to police as they were overdue by boat. A pilot later spotted a swamped boat on Cormorant Lake, Manitoba and advised police. Despite patrols and dragging operations Mr. Claus was never located. His partner was later found and the cause of death determined to be drowning. No foul play is suspected in this matter.

Case reference: 2005001499.CaseDesc: Lois was last seen shortly before midnight at the Village of Lucknow reunion dance on July 3, 1988. She left there and returned to her residence in Kincardine, Ontario where she resided alone. The police investigation indicates Lois was going through her usual evening routine before retiring. Lois, described as a devoted family person and a dedicated worker, failed to report for work on July 4, 1988. Her friends and family became concerned and notified police that she was missing.

Case reference: 2014003895.CaseDesc: On April 30, 1993, RCMP were advised Diana Thomas had fallen through the ice and had not surfaced. Diana was a passenger on a ski-doo along with her mother and a 13 year old driver. The threesome had only gone about 10 meters from shore when the back of the ski-doo went into the water, quickly followed by the front. Diana fell into the water with her mother and never resurfaced. Attempts were made to recover Diana, however all efforts met with negative results.

Case reference: 2014004957.CaseDesc: On New Year's Eve, 2002 an anonymous letter was received by the Vancouver Police Department. The letter referred to a female Vancouver sex trade worker who had disappeared one month earlier, at the end of November. The letter writer described the woman, admitted to killing her, and apologized to her family for taking her life. Investigators believe the letter writer was referring to Danielle Marissa Larue, and while her body has never been found, they believe that she was murdered. The letter writer knows what happened to Danielle, and police are hopeful that the writer will contact them again.

Case reference: 2012020142.CaseDesc: On September 10, 2008, Shannon Alexander, 17 and Maisy Odjick, 16, were reported missing from the First Nation community of Kitigan Zibi in Quebec. This community is located near the town of Maniwaki. On September 5, 2008, the two girls went to the Maniwaki arena, where several young people were present. Maisy then went to spend the night at Shannon’s house. Shannon’s father was the last person to have seen his daughter on September 6, 2008. Case reference: 2014030834.CaseDesc: On May 28, 1967 at approximately 9:00 a.m. John Pawloski, his common-law wife and a young boy (9 years old) were fishing in the area of Pointe du Bois, Manitoba. John's fishing rod started to slip into the water and he ran to reach at it. He fell into the fast moving water. His wife attempted to rescue him, but she too slipped on the rocks and fell into the water. The young boy ran to get help and when he looked back he could no longer see the couple.  The body of John's wife was found down the river shortly after the incident. Searches for John's body were done by air, land and water but the body was never found. He is presumed to have drowned.

Case reference: 2014001116.CaseDesc: On November 5, 1992, the skeletal remains of a man were found near Parksville on the Englishman River in British Colombia. The man had extensive dental restorations and may have been American. He recently had surgery for ingrown toenails, on both feet, and had a healed fracture to the left collarbone, which was repaired with a surgical wire. It is estimated that he may have died several months earlier.

Case reference: 2014002407.CaseDesc: Robert Scott Ellis and a friend headed out fishing on June 27, 1973. They left in the morning around 9:30 am and fished until around 6:00 pm when they decided to return home. During the course of the day, poor weather rolled in and the water became quite rough. They started taking in water over the sides of the canoe. Despite the progress they made, one wave eventually rolled the canoe. Both men hung onto the canoe for hours, but Robert eventually tired and let go.  When the friend eventually reached shore, he reported the incident. Dragging and diving operations were initiated and the results were negative. Mr. Ellis is presumed to have drowned. No foul play is suspected in this case.

PersonsData.Name: ELLIS, Robert Scott

Case reference: 2014005195.CaseDesc: Tommy Charpentier worked on a farm and lived with his employer in Sainte-Brigitte-des-Saults. On the night of December 15, 2008, tracks in the snow indicate that he may have walked on the Nicolet River that passes in front of the farm. Mr. Charpentier’s clothes were found on the frozen surface of the river, near an opening in the ice. This suggests that Mr. Charpentier may have jumped into the icy waters of the Nicolet River.

Case reference: 2014004969.CaseDesc: On July 21, 1966, a friend asked Ronnie Harper to help him lift one of his nets out of the waters of Red Sucker Lake. The two men set off in a canoe. When they arrived at the site, the men pulled the line attached to the net, but it didn't move. Increasing their efforts, the men pulled harder and the line attached to the weight came loose. The sudden shift caused both men to lose their footing and the canoe to overturn. The men attempted to move closer to shore by pushing the canoe. After a time, Mr. Harper told his friend he was too tired to hold on any longer. His companion continued moving the canoe. The survivor then realized Mr. Harper was no longer hanging on. Efforts to locate Mr. Harper were unsuccessful and it is presumed he drowned.

Case reference: 2014022293.CaseDesc: In February 1981, Emery LABOUCANE left his residence and went to work. While at work, he called his wife and stated he was on his way home. He never returned. His vehicle was later located at the Edmonton International Airport. LABOUCANE's credit cards were used in California over the course of the following month and then the usage ceased. No further activity was ever recorded on the credit cards.

Case reference: 2013000098.CaseDesc: On September 5, 1974, eight men were on a drilling barge. As they were making no headway against a strong current, it was agreed upon to park the barge for the night. The eight men worked together to park the vessel however one of the legs failed to lower, causing the barge to tip. Donald Bradburn was amongst the men who were thrown from the barge. Despite dragging operations Mr. Bradburn has never been located.

An extensive search failed to locate Mr. McFaul.  Several possible sightings were reported after August 15, 1986, but none led to Mr. McFaul's location.

Case reference: 2014002762.CaseDesc: On March 3rd, 1982, Laurence Peterson and Randolph Johanson were reported missing by Mr. Johanson’s girlfriend. Mr. Johanson and Mr. Peterson were last seen on February 28th, 1982, leaving the Shelter Island Marina, on their boats. Mr. Johanson was reportedly using his 26 ft. long salvage tug boat to haul Mr. Peterson’s 43 ft. wooden halibut fishing vessel to Lund, BC. The men were reported missing when they did not arrive at their destination. Extensive searches were unsuccessful. It has been speculated that the two men disappeared to start a new life.

Case reference: 2014001002.CaseDesc:
On June 27, 1979, the remains of a male were recovered from the Lower Niagara River about one mile south of the Boy Scout Camp and four miles from the St. Catharines Boat Club. 
His post-mortem weight was recorded as being between 150-160 lbs, however, this measurement may not represent his actual living weight due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy. He was recovered without clothing or jewelry. It is estimated that he had been in the water for several weeks prior to discovery.

Case reference: 2013000133.CaseDesc: On July 14, 2013, Prince Edward OPP (Picton) were advised of a 30 ft sailboat that had run aground on the shores at Point Petre (Lake Ontario). It was determined that the sailboat was from Rochester, New York and had left the Chimney Bluff State Park Marina (New York) on July 13,  2013 in the morning. Based on GPS tracks the investigators suspect that Scott French went overboard in American waters, and the boat drifted into Canadian Waters.

Case reference: 2014004206.CaseDesc: On September 18, 1988, 3 people were visiting Leonard Kalichak at his residence and had decided to go out in a boat on Lake Dauphin, Manitoba. When they left shore they were faced with adverse conditions subsequently capsizing the boat. At this point, Mr. Kalichak immediately went under the water, possibly as a result of heavy clothing or an injury sustained when the boat capsized. Searches were conducted by land, air, water and dragging operations on the lake. Leonard Kalichak has never been found and he is presumed dead due to drowning.

Case reference: 2005007699.CaseDesc: On July 9, 1986, a Caucasian male was found in the Don River, near 62 Villiers Street, in Toronto, Ontario. He was estimated to be between 25-45 years old. His post-mortem weight was recorded as being 140 lbs and his length was measured at 5’11", however, these measurements may not represent his actual living weight and height due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy. His teeth show heavy tartar accumulation and tobacco stain. His appendix was present and he was circumcised. He is thought to have been dead for a few days to a few weeks.

Case reference: 2014002821.CaseDesc: During the weekend of August 18, 1972, Dennis Simpson and a friend left for a fishing trip on McMillian Lake. When they failed to return by the 22nd, numerous people contacted police. Through investigation it was later determined that both men were last seen by a man on shore on Sunday the 20th, and their camp was still set up. They told the individual that they were going to make one more pass and then intended to break camp. Weather conditions at the time were such that there would have been rough water. Given this and the fact that the men were in a fairly small canoe, it was determined they may have capsized. An extensive land, water and air search did not find anything other than various articles that were identified as belonging to the two missing fishermen. Mr. Simpson has never been located.

Case reference: 2012020061.CaseDesc: On the evening of October 17, 2008, Amber Mcfarland went to Smitty's lounge with her boyfriend and an acquaintance of his. There they socialized with friends for a while and then moved to the bar at the Canad Inn. They left Amber's vehicle at the Canad Inn and went to the Cat and Fiddle Bar where they continued to socialize. Video surveillance at the bar confirms that shortly after 1:00 am on October 18, 2008, Amber, her boyfriend and his acquaintance entered the attached beer vendor and purchased a case of beer. The three of them exited the vendor and walked into the parking lot. Amber has not been seen or heard from since. All of Amber's cell phone activity and bank activity has since ceased.

Case reference: 2006000499.CaseDesc:
On July 12, 1989, the body of a male was recovered from the Whirlpool basin in the Niagara River. 
His post-mortem weight was recorded as being 167lbs and his length was measured to be between  5’9"-5’10", however, these measurements may not represent his actual living weight and height due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy.
His appendix was present.
He was recovered without any clothing or personal effects. It is estimated that he had been in the water for some days to weeks prior to recovery.

Case reference: 2013000095.CaseDesc: On October 19, 1969 Ronald Bonkowski went fishing with two friends in the Winnipeg River. Upon arriving at their desired location, the party anchored their boat in fast moving water. The anchor caught on the bottom of the river and pulled the boat down, causing it to over turn. All three men were thrown into the water. Two of the men were able to swim to the shore, however Mr. Bonkowski was observed going under the water. The over turned boat was found with an anchor line attached at the dam site. Searches were conducted by water and land, however Ronald Bonkowski was never located. He is presumed dead due to drowning.

Case reference: 2015066998.CaseDesc:
Yvon Shawn Guignard moved to the northern part of Manitoba during the summer of 2015 in search of employment, with interests in Churchill and the Northwest Territories. While in Thompson, he adopted a transient lifestyle, living in his personal vehicle and developing friendships with the homeless community. 
It’s believed Mr. Guignard was last seen on November 28, 2015 at approximately 6:45am. Just prior to his disappearance, he made a number of attempts to give away his personal vehicle, which was located at the time he was reported missing. According to his family, he is schizophrenic, with a medical condition and he also has a history of not taking his prescription medications. He has been known to travel to undisclosed locations within the country and act secretive with family as to his whereabouts. He should not be approached as he may be in medical distress.

Case reference: 2006012299.CaseDesc: On June 02, 1984, Andrew Grinnell, his brother,their cousin and a friend  departed Sioux Lookout on a canoe trip on the Albany River. The party arrived in Fort Albany on July 18, 1984. At 6:00 p.m. that same day, the party decided to leave Fort Albany in an attempt to paddle to Moosonee via James Bay. The group had planned to go out onto James Bay with the tide and sail to Moosonee by lashing their canoes together. An intense storm engulfed the James Bay coastal area on July 23, 1984, and it is likely that the party perished on the Bay during this storm. Three victims were recovered in August 1984, twelve nautical miles North of the Moose River. Mr. Grinnell's body has never been recovered.

On August 19, 1994, the body of a Caucasian male was found in the Niagara River. 
His post-mortem weight was recorded as being 134 lbs and his length was measured between 5’8"-5’9",  however, these measurements may not represent his actual living weight and height due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy.
His appendix was present. He is believed to have been in the water several days to weeks.

Case reference: 2010001799.CaseDesc: On the morning of May 18, 1993, Christine Harron stayed home from school as she was not feeling well. Around lunch time Christine and her mother argued about Christine returning to school for the afternoon. Her mother heard Christine leave the house at about 1:30 pm. Christine did not attend school that afternoon and she has not been seen since. The investigation revealed that Christine left the house without her purse, money or knapsack. Subsequent investigation has led to the arrest and conviction of a male in regards to the disappearance of Christine Harron, however her remains have yet to be located.

Case reference: 2014003748.CaseDesc: On September 29th, 1996, police were contacted by a friend to report his 3 hunting partners, including Glen Mymryk who were overdue from a hunting trip. He also advised he found one of the barrels from the boat they took, floating towards shore and he could see something on the lake through the binoculars but was unsure what it was. The three men left in a loaded boat and got halfway to their destination when they decided the water conditions were too bad and they turned around. The men were bailing but the waves were too much, the motor stalled and they capsized. Mr. Mymryk was last seen floating away soon after the boat capsized. The lone survivor was rescued 7 hours after the incident and indicate the other 2 men he was with had drowned.

Case reference: 2014001165.CaseDesc: On September 22, 2005, the body of an adult male was recovered from the lower Niagara River. His post-mortem weight was recorded as being 174 lbs and his length was measured at 5'6", however, these measurements may not represent his actual living weight and height due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy. His teeth are stained suggesting that he may have been a smoker. He is circumcised and his appendix is present. He was not wearing any clothing or jewelry. It is believed that he had been in the water for a few days prior to his recovery.

Case reference: 2014002843.CaseDesc: A party of 6 men departed Churchill, Manitoba, on a fishing trip traveling in three canoes. On June 20, 1967, two of the three canoes became stranded on mud flats at a point where the Hayes and Nelson Rivers empty into the Hudson Bay. The men made camp for the night and then the following day Kurt Hild, Ronald Davidson and James Cochrane all attempted to retrieve the stranded canoes. On return to the camp the men were confronted with high winds and freezing rain which forced them out of sight. None of the remains of the men have been recovered. Foul play is not suspected in the matter.

Case reference: 2012001299.CaseDesc: On October 17, 1991, a male was found on the shoreline of Sandy Beach in Michipicoten Harbour, Lake Superior, near Wawa. His post-mortem weight was recorded as being 165 lbs; however, this measurement may not represent his actual living weight due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy. His appendix was present. He is thought to have been dead from a few weeks to a few months.

Case reference: 2014001632.CaseDesc: Elizabeth Dorion was last seen by a friend at a local fishing camp on September 21, 1999. Ms. Dorion arrived at the fishing camp on the 17th of September with her friends and stayed there approximately 4 days. She was never seen again. Two separate ground searches were carried out. Several steep embankments as well as the area surrounding the camp were searched with negative results. Ms. Dorion's whereabouts remain unknown.

Case reference: 2006000699.CaseDesc:
On January 31, 1988, a male was found on the Don Valley Parkway, having jumped from the Bloor Street Viaduct in Toronto. He is described as a dark-skinned Caucasian. His post-mortem length was recorded as being approximately 5’5"-5'6", however, this measurement may not represent his actual living length due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy.  
He has a thick beard and moustache. He also has a significant amount of body hair. His appendix is present.

Case reference: 2014002562.CaseDesc: Michael Megraw, from Minnesota, USA, had visited the Katamik Lake area with his brother to go fishing over the September Labour Day weekend in September 1992.  Michael had returned to the US but was reported missing just days later, family indicated he was last seen on September 11, 1992.  RCMP received a call on October 3, 1992, about a truck at Katamik Lake which didn't appear to have been moved since September 24th; Mr. Megraw was determined to be the registered owner.  It is believed he returned to the lake somewhere between September 11 and September 24, 1992. Mr. Megraw has not been seen since.

Case reference: 2013000125.CaseDesc: Bonnie Joan Thomas (née Cooper) of Rollingdam, just outside of St. Stephen, NB, met with some friends and went across the U.S. border to the Legion in Calais, Maine.  They went to a St. Patrick's Day dance. After the evening's celebrations, Bonnie left the Legion alone in her red 1973 Volvo station wagon. She drove back through the Calais/St. Stephen border crossing into Canada. At the Canadian entry point Bonnie hit the customs booth causing minor damage to her car. She was last seen talking to the Customs Officer. The next morning her husband realized she was missing, and called the police. Bonnie's car was found abandoned on March 18, 1978, near St. Stephen on a logging road near the St Croix River.

Case reference: 2006017399.CaseDesc: Mary Frances Gregory left her home in Parry Sound, Ontario on February 15, 1978, to vacation in California. She failed to arrive at her destination in Palo Alto, California and has not contacted any family members or friends since. Ms. Gregory is believed to have departed Canada by motor vehicle with a male acquaintance who states that he let her off at a bus station in Las Vegas, Nevada some ten days after leaving Canada. The driver claims to have driven to Nevada via the States of New York, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Illinois, Colorado, Utah, and Arizona.

Case reference: 2012020081.CaseDesc: Emily Osmond (Laplante) lived a reclusive lifestyle on a small acreage on the Northern edge of Kawacatoose First Nation. Emily seldom had contact with her family or friends and the last known contact with them was August 29, 2007. She was last seen on the 9th of September, 2007, by her hired helper. Her disappearance is very unusual. Her vehicle and personal belongings including medication were left at her residence. She also had dogs at her acreage that she cared for that were left unattended. Searches of the area have failed to locate any sign of Emily.
