Case reference: 2014003848.CaseDesc: On November 5, 1964, the Grand Rapids RCMP was advised that there were rumors that Harvey Hudson was two weeks over due in returning from a trip to Cedar Lake from Grand Rapids. After numerous inquiries it was discovered M. Hudson left The Pas Manitoba on October 20th and arrived at Cedar Lake Post.  When he reached Cedar Lake, M. Hudson was advised by a friend to wait for a boat from Easterville which was expected shortly. A witness who spoke to M. Hudson indicated that he first left on foot for Easterville but turned back. He then took a canoe and started off for Easterville using a piece of board as a paddle. It is believed that Mr. Hudson had little or no food, no rifle or other camping gear. Numerous land, air and water patrols were made with negative results.

Case reference: 2005000599.CaseDesc: On May 18, 2005, this male, believed to be Caucasian was found on the bank of a reservoir in the "Pine Valley Open Space" located at 7211 Pine Valley Road, north of Highway 7, in Vaughan, Ontario. Nearby bed linens, clothing, personal belongings and food suggest that this person was homeless and living by the reservoir. The state of preservation of the remains is suggestive of a lengthy time since death (greater than one year) however, a newspaper dated to January 9, 2005 was found amongst this man's belongings suggesting a post-mortem interval of 4 months.

Case reference: 2016069147.CaseDesc: On September 13, 1974, the body of a Caucasian male was found on the CNR tracks, 200 yards west of the CNR Station, Hearst. A witness observed the remains on the tracks after an advancing train had passed. His post-mortem length was recorded as being 5’8” however; this measurement may not represent his actual living height due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy. He was described as having a medium build. He may have been wearing glasses according to police reports.

Case reference: 2005003399.CaseDesc: On May 12, 2004, an unidentified man was recovered from the Whirlpool in the Lower Niagara River. His post-mortem weight was recorded as being 200 lbs. and his length was measured at 6'0", however these measurements may not represent his actual living weight and height due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy. This male is uncircumcised, and his appendix is present. It is believed that this individual had been in the water for less than 3 weeks but it is also possible that the body could have been in the water over the winter.

Case reference: 2014002167.CaseDesc: On July 7th, 1973, Mr. Gorrie and his family were seen returning from a day of fishing on Cross Lake by the local RCMP patrol. Mr. Gorrie followed the patrol boat for some time and eventually the family boarded the patrol boat while Mr. Gorrie continued to follow in his boat. Both vessels proceeded west however after a time, the height of the waves increased (7 to 8 ft.). As a result the patrol boat had to increase power, which substantially increased the distance between the respective boats. Mr. Gorrie's boat was last seen a 1/2 mile behind the patrol. Immediate searches by air provided negative results. It is presumed that Mr. Gorrie drowned as he or the boat have never been located.

PersonsData.Name: GORRIE, William Aylmer

Case reference: 2014007309.CaseDesc: On August 20, 1997, a canoeist found a human skull on the Moose Jaw River, just south of Moose Jaw, SK. The skull was examined by the University Of Saskatchewan Department Of Archaeology. It was determined the skull had been exposed to the elements for 50 to 100 years. It was that of a 12 year old, possibly Caucasian, female. This case is being investigated by the Office of the Chief Coroner and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

Case reference: 2014003393.CaseDesc: James Siwy's last confirmed contact with his family was in 1982 in the Drumheller, Alberta area.  Shortly after that, he left Alberta for Ontario with some friends.  They were traveling in Mr. Siwy's 1975 white Dodge 4 door Monaco that had a burgundy roof.  His family never heard from him again.  In 1984 Mr. Siwy's Monaco was found abandoned in Ontario and there were unconfirmed reports that he may have been hitchhiking in northern Ontario.  Mr. Siwy was reported missing by his family in 1994 when they tried to notify him of the death of a family member.

Case reference: 2014001428.CaseDesc: On May 19, 1998, at approximately 7:00 p.m., Rémi Engrand left a residence for men in Valleyfield, Quebec, for a walk with two other residents of the center where he had been staying for a few days. They went to the Delpha-Sauvé Park, where Rémi wanted to go swimming in the river, near the waterfall. The three separated, leaving Rémi alone and when they returned, they found Rémi’s clothes on the shoreline. The current in this section of the river is very fast and the presence of the falls makes swimming very risky. Rémi has not been seen since this time.

Case reference: 2012020121.CaseDesc: Mathieu Beauregard Messier was alone at home with his wife. At approximately 7:00 p.m., Mathieu told his wife he had to go see a friend and that he would be back later in the evening. He left alone in his wife’s vehicle and with her cellphone. At approximately 10:30 p.m., police received a call that a vehicle was on fire on Rang du Haut-de-la-Rivière, near the military base in Farnham, Quebec. The vehicle was identified as that of Mathieu’s wife. There was nobody inside the vehicle, and Mathieu has not been seen or heard from since.

Case reference: 2016065871.CaseDesc:
On May 10, 1973, a male, approximately 170 lbs., 5'6"-5'8" in height, robbed the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce on Main Street South in Kenora. He was subsequently shot by police upon getaway which detonated the explosive device that was carried on his body. 
It was later determined that this individual had spent 2 days at the hotel between April 23 and 25, checking-in under the name of "Paul Higgins, 435 Glen Dr., Toronto". Upon check-out, he apparently took a bus to Winnipeg but arranged to have his steamer trunk stored at the hotel. He checked back into the hotel on May 5. The steamer trunk was found in his room following the robbery along with items that were disposed of by the Armed Forces Demolition Unit. The remains of Old Port, Dutch Prince and Teuros-Havanas cigars and cigar packages were also found in his room. The name and address that this individual provided upon check-in were followed-up with negative results.

On November 6, 2016, Maxwell Harvey Mayling was reported missing from Prince George, British Columbia.  Mr. Mayling was last heard from in early October, 2016 by friends and family.  Mr. Mayling is known to frequent both the Prince George and Fort St John municipalities, and was last known to have been in Prince George since July 2016.

Case reference: 2011002099.CaseDesc: On May 11, 2011, James Pratt attended his cottage property on Boulter Road in Hasting Highland. He said he was going to check on his trailer and outbuilding. On the afternoon of May 11th, a friend attended the Pratt property and found Mr. Pratt's car, but Mr. Pratt was not around. The friend returned on the 12th of May and discovered the car had not been moved. He searched the property for Mr. Pratt but he could not be found. Mr. Pratt has the reputation as a wanderer and it was not unusual for him to disappear for days at a time. This time however, he had left all of his belongings behind. The Bancroft OPP were notified on May 15th. A search was conducted but Mr. Pratt was not located. He suffers from medical problems including high blood pressure.

Case reference: 2013000096.CaseDesc: On May 6, 1972 a four man fishing and trapping team was returning from Lynn Lake on dog sleds after purchasing supplies. Mr. Bonner and his friend were in the lead sled. The team that was traveling with them was approximately 2.5 km behind. When approximately 183 metres from Mr. Bonner's sled, they noticed both men had gone through the ice. Once on scene both men had disappeared beneath the water. One of the men was pulled from the water but could not be revived. Mr. Bonner never resurfaced and despite dragging operations he could not be located.

Case reference: 2014002684.CaseDesc: On February 16, 1994, Mathieu Landry was reported missing by a traveling companion. Mr. Landry was renting a cabin at Juara village on Tioman Island in Malaysia when he went for a walk and never returned. Sunglasses belonging to Landry where found on the beach. His passport, clothing, backpack and other personal effects where recovered from the resort where he was staying. Land and water searches involving police divers where done and failed to locate him; he was presumed to have drowned.

Case reference: 2014001333.CaseDesc: On May 18, 1975, members of the Canadian Armed Forces located the personal belongings of William Bereziuk washed up on an island in the Athabasca River 50 km north of Fort McMurray, Alberta. Mr. Bereziuk left Edmonton, Alberta in October of 1974 with the intention of making a canoe trip down the Athabasca River. He informed family members that he intended to spend the winter of 1974 in the Birch Mountain area of Alberta and would return to Edmonton in August of 1975. Mr. Bereziuk has never been heard from since.

Case reference: 2014003840.CaseDesc: On December 7, 1986, a male was seen floating in the river. The male initially responded to police calls however shortly after he was observed going under the water. It is presumed he drowned. The identity of the male was unknown to police until Roderick Cook's parents contacted police advising they had not seen their son for some time. It is assumed the man in the river was Roderick based both on the description and the fact that he was seen walking near the river. Police further found footprints that led from the shore to the open water. No foul play is suspected in this matter and it is assumed Mr. Cook drowned.

Case reference: 2013000099.CaseDesc: William Andersen and a co-worker were designated to conduct a wildlife survey in northern Manitoba. The men had flown into North Indian Lake on June 26th and departed by canoe from there. On the second day when the men attempted to shoot some rapids, their canoe hit a rock which overturned, throwing both men into the river. Mr. Andersen was not seen again. Air and land searches failed to locate Mr. Andersen and he is presumed dead as a result of drowning. No foul play is suspected in this matter.

Case reference: 2009003699.CaseDesc: Michel Gagich, who typically goes by his middle name: Steve, was last seen by his father on Saturday, September 5, 2009 at his residence in Hamilton.  He left his residence on Sunday, September 6, 2009 in the morning, around 8:00 a.m. without speaking to his parents.  He left a note indicating that he was leaving for the weekend. Mr. Gagich's vehicle was located on Tuesday, September 8, 2009 at approximately 7:15 p.m. when a passing airplane observed a fire.  By the time the fire department arrived the vehicle was completely burned.  The vehicle was located in a remote area on Emmett Lake Road in St. Edmund's Township.  Mr. Gagich was last seen at the Tobermory Ferry Terminal on Wednesday, September 9, 2009 at 7 a.m.  It is not known if he purchased a ticket to board the ferry.  The MS Chi Cheemaun ferry provides transportation for vehicles and people from Tobermory to South Baymouth on Manitoulin Island.

Case reference: 2014006315.CaseDesc: Julia STROBACH was last seen in her residence on Braidwood Road in Courtenay, British Columbia on October 31st, 2013 in the early evening hours.  Unfortunately, after a lengthy and comprehensive investigation police have been unable to find any trace of Julia.  Police along with Julia’s friends and family are gravely concerned for Julia's wellbeing as she has been out of contact for a year now.  It is completely out of character for Julia to be out of contact with her friends and family for so long, especially with her 3 year old son.  Police are appealing to anyone with information about Julia's movements and activities in the days and weeks leading up to October 31st, 2013, to get in touch with investigators immediately.

Case reference: 2014006098.CaseDesc: On March 12, 2012, Mr. Ménard left Quebec to travel to Mexico by car with his dog. When returning home on March 14, 2013, he was denied entry to the United States at the US Customs in Nuevo Laredo because his dog was carrying ticks. Therefore, he stayed in Mexico and has not been seen since. His vehicle and his dog were recovered after having been stolen. The individuals interviewed for the vehicle theft provided no information into Mr. Ménard's disappearance.

Case reference: 2012020074.CaseDesc: On August 22, 1988 Cathy Williams left her residence in St. Andrews, Manitoba to go to Winnipeg to fill out a job application.  She had made arrangements to meet a male acquaintance who was going to help her complete the application.  During the late afternoon and early evening, Cathy and her friend attended two bars and eventually ended up at a restaurant.  Cathy left her friend at the restaurant.  From the restaurant, Cathy attended the residence of another male acquaintance who invited her in for a visit.  She indicated she had to get her purse from her friends car and she was going to be back in half an hour.  This was the last time Cathy Williams was seen.  Cathy was reported missing by her mother on the morning of August 23, 1988.  Cathy has not been heard from again and her body has never been recovered.

Case reference: 2010003499.CaseDesc:
On March 21, 2010 Chung Law left work on Dundas St, London ON. He told his employer that he was experiencing some stress and would be taking a couple of days off. Mr. Law spoke to his wife, who lives in Vaughan, ON, and told her he was coming home for a visit. He spoke to his employer the next day, saying he was in Toronto and that he did not want to return to work in London. Mr. Law never did arrive home. Investigation has revealed that Mr. Law may have travelled to Toronto by bus. 

In April, 2011 a right foot contained within a black boot was located in the river flats of the Thames River in Elgin County. The area was searched and no further remains were found. DNA confirmed that the foot was that of Mr. Law.

Case reference: 2014003731.CaseDesc: On October 30, 1964 at 1:00 p.m. Murray Hansen left Berens River, Manitoba to go to Black River to deliver some items to a family member. At approximately 3:00 p.m. that day it started to storm and the water on the lake became rough. Mr. Hansen planned to stay in Black River overnight and then return to Berens River. When 5 days passed and he hadn't returned home, his wife began to look for him and discovered that he had never arrived in Black River. On November 3, 1964, Mr. Hansen's boat was found turned over near Bigstone Point and was approximately 100 yards from the shore. Searches were done by air, land and boat but the body of Mr. Hansen was never recovered. Murray Hansen is presumed dead due to drowning.

Case reference: 2014001814.CaseDesc: On October 27, 1973, between 2:00pm and 5:00pm Steve Mysick packed a suitcase and left the residence where he was staying, located in Rapid City, Manitoba. Steve Mysick was an outpatient of the Brandon Mental Hospital and had been staying with his friends for 2.5 years at the time of his disappearance.   Mr. Mysick was last seen at the CP train station in Brandon, Manitoba. It is likely Mr. Mysick purchased the ticket to Winnipeg as he had very limited funds available and had lived in Winnipeg in the past. There is no indication if Mr. Mysick actually boarded the train to Winnipeg.   Steve Mysick has never been located and his whereabouts is unknown. Foul play is not suspected.

Case reference: 2016068415.CaseDesc:
On July 17, 1975 a "Hush Puppy" style loafer shoe, size 10, containing a skeletonized left foot was found on the south shore of the Ottawa River in Chute a Blondeau, Ontario. The colour of the shoe is not discernible. 
Examination of the foot bones by a Forensic Pathologist revealed that this individual may be a male, aged 20-50 years, 5'10" to 6'1" in height, 200-230 lbs., with no abnormalities of the foot bones and no arthritis. The Forensic Pathologist had estimated that death occurred in excess of one year to possibly 5 years.

Case reference: 2014004353.CaseDesc: On June 23, 2002 RCMP received a call reporting a missing person in the Village of Makinak. Reported missing was George Turnbull, 82 years old. George was last seen on June 22, 2002 at approximately 8:00 pm by a home care worker and was last spoken to on the phone by his son at approximately 10:00 pm that same day. The home care worker arrived at approximately 9:00 am on June 23, 2002 and noticed at that time George was not in his residence. At approximately 10:00 am the family began to search in and around the area of George's residence and farm yard. He suffers from mild dementia and has wandered off before. Volunteers continued to search for him until June 26, 2002 at which point the search was called off. George Turnbull was not seen again.

Case reference: 2014003922.CaseDesc: On Saturday July 15, 1972, Mr. Zukewhich and a friend took a canoe on to Clearwater Lake. Witnesses state that both men were under the influence of alcohol and that they took alcohol with them into the canoe. Witnesses further noted that the lake was extremely rough due to high winds. Mr. Zukewhich and friend were seen departing around 1600 hrs heading towards an area known as Long Point. A resident of Long Point advised police he observed one person in the red canoe which was sitting flat indicating weight in the front. The canoe was recovered on July 17th. Despite extensive searching, Mr. Zukewhich was never located.

Case reference: 2014004179.CaseDesc: Leona Brule from Fort Providence, NT, was reported missing by her mother in 1989.  Her mother had not heard from Leona for over a year.  Leona was considered transient at the time of her disappearance, and drug and alcohol use/abuse was suspected.  Some evidence indicated that Leona may have been on the streets in Edmonton AB in the1990's.  There was also a possible link to Florida.  Leona's disappearance was deemed suspicious from the onset due to high risk transient lifestyle.

Case reference: 2014003009.CaseDesc: On the evening of September 30, 1979, Adolphe Thorassie and three hunting partners were attempting to return home after a successful hunt. Two men were in each boat. On the return trip the men had to go to shore once to get out of the winds. They again departed despite the high winds on the lake which was causing the water to be extremely dangerous with high waves. Adolphe was in the lead boat with his hunting partner, and unbeknownst to him the second boat had to return to shore for motor repairs. Adolphe and his hunting partner never returned and were reported missing the next day. The body of Adolphe's hunting partner was discovered and the cause of death was determined to be drowning. It is assumed Mr. Thorassie also drowned.

PersonsData.Name: THORASSIE, Adolphe

Case reference: 2014003382.CaseDesc: On May 27, 1988, Mr. Umpherville and a friend were driving to The Pas where they stayed the night. In the morning the two departed The Pas via 20 foot yawl with the intent on going to Easterville. They departed the Umpherville settlement around 1300hrs and they briefly stopped at Pine Bluff around 1600 hrs. It is believed they then stopped at a friends trappers cabin at Rat Hunting and ate a meal. The last thing the survivor remembers, is seeing the lights of Easterville and he crawled to the front of the boat where he fell asleep. He awoke around 0500 hrs the next day and Mr. Umpherville was no longer in the boat and he was adrift. Numerous islands in the area were searched, shorelines were searched and several air and water patrols were made without success. Mr. Umpherville has not been located and his whereabouts is unknown.

Case reference: 2012020024.CaseDesc: On February 24, 1995 what appeared to be a partial skull with an attached vertebra was located near a creek; just south of Highway 7, approximately 800 metres east of the Ruskin Bridge in Mission, B.C.  A DNA profile confirmed that this person was a female, and her DNA profile has been provided to every laboratory in Canada and shared with Interpol.  In August 2002, bones recovered during a search of a farm associated to Robert Pickton were confirmed to be genetically linked to this partial skull.  It is possible that this woman's family does not know that she is missing or may be under the mistaken belief that she was reported missing and there is a file open.

Case reference: 2014004744.CaseDesc: Cyril Detimmerman and a friend left Brandon, Manitoba on the Assiniboine River traveling to Treherne. Cyril was experienced at navigating along this river route, however water conditions at that time had been very high as a result of the spring flooding. The pair soon encountered strong currents and large amounts of debris on the river. In the process of trying to navigate to shore the boat capsized causing both men to enter the water. Both men were wearing life jackets. Extensive searches conducted by land, air, water and dragging operations several miles along the river all with negative results. Mr. Detimmerman was never found and is presumed dead due to drowning.

PersonsData.Name: DETIMMERMAN, Cyril

Case reference: 2016068410.CaseDesc: On September 10, 1966, the body of a Caucasian male was recovered from the Grand River in Onondaga Township, Brant County. His post-mortem weight was recorded as being 170lbs, however, this measurement may not represent his actual living weight due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy. This individual consumed a large meal of corn shortly before his death. He was uncircumcised. It is estimated that he died in the latter half of August or early in September 1966.

Case reference: 2014001522.CaseDesc: On July 7, 1977, James Stackhouse and a friend were camped on a small island on the east shore of Lake Winnipeg, north of Hole River where they were doing some mapping. Their boat drifted away to the south towards Deer Island located 3 miles south. At approximately 6:00 p.m. both men left the shore holding onto some small logs that they had tied together with their belts. They attempted to swim to Deer Island but the current and the waves carried them to 1/4 mile east of Deer Island. The bundle of logs that they had tied broke and the men were separated. Mr. Stackhouse's friend managed to swim to Deer Island but he did not see Mr. Stackhouse again. Searches of the area were done by land, air and water but the body of Mr. Stackhouse was not recovered. He is presumed deceased due to drowning.

PersonsData.Name: STACKHOUSE, James

Case reference: 2014001218.CaseDesc: On June 24, 1974, the body of an adult female was found approximately 19 miles Northeast of Penticton near Chute Lake Road, Naramata. The body was located down an embankment beside an isolated narrow dirt road in a heavily wooded area. It is estimated that the body had been at this location for a couple of months. It was noted that the female’s teeth were in good condition and she had high quality fillings that were done within two or three years prior to death. Minor orthodontist work was done when the female was a young girl.

Case reference: 2006002999.CaseDesc: The body of this adult male was located in a laneway behind 1556 Bloor Street West near Dundas Street in Toronto on March 21, 1997. He was thought to be a homeless person who frequented the area on a daily basis. Although he appears to be somewhat older, there are no arthritic changes to his bones, which are typical of older individuals. His post-mortem weight was recorded as being 150 lbs and his length was measured at 5'9", however, these measurements may not represent his actual living weight and height due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy.

Case reference: 2014002095.CaseDesc: On May 10, 1980 four men from Grand Forks, North Dakota departed in a boat from the Anama Bay Tourist Camp (Manitoba) for a fishing trip. At approximately 2:45 p.m. on this date an overturned boat was spotted in the Sturgeon Bay area of Lake Winnipeg. The bodies of three of the four men were found. The cause of death for all three of these men was death due to cold exposure (in water) and drowning. The body of William Winters was never recovered. He is presumed dead due to drowning.

Case reference: 2014005517.CaseDesc:
At the time of her disappearance, Amber Guiboche was living in the north end of Winnipeg with her boyfriend and his family. Amber had been leading a high-risk lifestyle.

Amber spent the evening of November 10th, 2010 socializing with friends, later that evening she went to a friend’s residence on Bushnell St. She left there alone at around 11:45 p.m., and walked to the intersection of Isabel Street and William Ave.  

She was picked up there shortly after by a man driving a burgundy pickup truck. The truck was described as an older, burgundy Chevrolet Silverado, extended cab, short box with a “4x4” decal toward the rear of the box. 

The truck was last seen traveling southbound on Isabel St. It was captured on video in the area in which she was last seen.

Images of this truck and a forensic artist’s sketch of the driver have been made available.

Case reference: 2014004377.CaseDesc: On October 3, 2003, a family member contacted Police and reported that ROSS had been missing since the evening of October 1st. She indicated ROSS and his cousin were drinking together that night and that on their way home his cousin lost sight of ROSS in the bushes. ROSS did not return home. Numerous sightings were reported to police in the days following ROSS' disappearance however no one spoke directly to ROSS. As a result these sightings are unconfirmed. Further unconfirmed sightings were reported across Canada as well and were investigated. ROSS has not been located and his whereabouts are unknown.

Emma did not use or abuse drugs or alcohol.

Case reference: 2016061146.CaseDesc: On October 17, 1964, the body of what was described as a young male was recovered from Lake Erie, off the tip of Long Point, adjacent to the Township of South Walsingham, County Norfolk. His post-mortem weight was recorded at approximately 190 lbs. Due to decompositional changes and post-mortem injury, this may not be an accurate reflection of his living weight. His appendix was present. It is believed that he had been in the water for a minimum of 3 months.

Case reference: 2012020130.CaseDesc:
Mario Marabella, 40 years old, was on his way to a meeting when he was abducted on December 4, 2008 in Laval.  Mr. Marabella was at a service station on Highway 440 between Hwys. 19 and 25 around 4:00 p.m. when three people forced him into a van and fled. 

Mr. Marabella's car, a grey Acura MDX was retrieved around 8:00 p.m. that evening by one or more of the abductors at the same Petro-Canada station from which Mr. Marabella was abducted. A few hours later the car was found burning at the corner of Gouin Boulevard and Lambert St. in Montréal.  Mr. Marabella was known to be involved in organized crime.  He was linked to the Italian Mafia.

Case reference: 2014032043.CaseDesc:
On May 22nd, 1970, Philomena Sisson, age 68, was reported missing by her son, Harry Jack.  She had gone missing a few days earlier from his house on Boys Rd. in Duncan, BC.  Mrs. Sisson was reported to be an alcoholic who occasionally went missing for several days at a time. She also suffered from dementia. 
 
Mrs. Sisson's last surviving son has since passed away.  There was never any indication of foul play in her disappearance.

Case reference: 2014006177.CaseDesc: On October 9, 1987, at approximately 9:00 p.m. Phillip Orvis went out onto the lake in his boat from Matheson Island. He was planning to go to his fishing camp at Black Bear Island. At the time that he left the water on the lake was very rough. Phillip could not swim and he was known to never wear a life jacket. His boat was found the next day drifted up against the mainland approximately 1/2 mile south east of the dock where he is believed to have left from. The boat was filled with water. Searches were conducted by land, air and water and dragging operations were conducted on the lake however his body was never located. Phillip Orvis is presumed dead due to drowning and foul play is not suspected.

Case reference: 2014003366.CaseDesc: The morning of July 8, 1981,  the Happy Valley-Goose Bay RCMP were notified that an aluminum boat with an outboard motor was going in circles just out from the new houses in Sheshatshiu, NL.  Police were advised that the boat was unoccupied and travelling quite fast in circles. The investigation determined that the boat had been once occupied by John Morris Groves of North West River, NL and it appears that he had fallen overboard.  The body of Mr. Groves has not yet been located.

Case reference: 2014005607.CaseDesc: Eleanor Eatha Parkinson-Jenkins was last seen on Monday March 1, 1982. At that time, she was living in Saint-Bruno-de Montarville. She was reported missing by her family. Ms. Parkinson-Jenkins had been ill for the past six months. She would normally leave a note when she left, but not that morning. She usually spent her days in bed or never went out alone. She would have left after the departure of her husband and did not take her purse with her. She left on foot and never came back. She is a originally from Ottawa, Ontario.

Case reference: 2013000136.CaseDesc: Mr. Joseph Moore was last seen on October 31, 2012 by his employer in Kincardine, Ontario.  He was reported missing on November 12, 2012. Upon investigation, M. Moore's apartment was found neat and tidy and his clothing and luggage had been left behind. Joseph Moore is known to suffer from severe cases of depression. The last potential sighting was at the Kincardine Davidson Centre on November 8, 2012.  A media blitz was done to request feedback for missing person Joseph Moore with limited feedback. An extensive search of the area was conducted with negative results.

Case reference: 2008007999.CaseDesc: On September 19, 1980, Charles Leslie Lewis and a friend were out fishing on Gull Rock Lake approximately 10km south of Red Lake. While they were out on the lake the winds picked up and began to create large waves, which caused the boat to capsize. Mr. Lewis and his friend clung to the bottom of the boat but were pushed off several times by the waves. Mr. Lewis was washed away from the boat. As he attempted to swim back to the boat, his head kept going under water.  At one point he did not resurface.

Case reference: 2014001826.CaseDesc: On November 5, 1960, Andrew Moses was last seen as he left his base camp on Brunswick Lake in Algoma County, Ontario. Andrew had left the base camp to check his trap line, which was approximately 5 miles in length near Ericson Creek. On November 13, 1960, a small search group was formed when Andrew did not return. The group located a rifle belonging to Andrew leaning against a tree. The following day, a half eaten beaver was located inside of a nearby camp on Ericson creek. The camp and trap line were searched one year later, and it revealed that it was vacant with no signs of being visited.

Case reference: 2013000101.CaseDesc: Oswald Bear left his parents home in Peguis First Nation, Manitoba to go to the bush a short distance east of the house and cut some wood. Mr. Bear was very familiar with the area and enjoyed chopping wood. He spent a lot of time there and knew it well. He had never been lost in the bush and had never failed to return home previously. He visited at his sister's residence nearby at 6:15 p.m. Shortly thereafter, his sister told him that he should go home so that their mother wouldn't worry. When Mr. Bear left his sisters's residence, his intention was to go home, but he has not been seen since.

Case reference: 2008023299.CaseDesc: In the early morning hours of June 30, 2001, Istefan Toma returned home after work. He showered, changed his clothes and was observed leaving the family home at approximately 1 a.m. in his own vehicle. It was later discovered he had taken his identification and citizenship card, but did not take any clothing or other belongings with him. His vehicle was recovered from a parking lot in the vicinity of his work place at Woodbridge Mall (Hwy 7/Martingrove, Woodbridge, Ontario) on the 11th of February 2002, having been parked there for approximately 6-9 months. Mr. Toma has not been in contact with any family members nor his employers since he left his home on the morning of June 30, 2001. Mr. Toma speaks broken English, is known to smoke DuMaurier cigarettes and has been known to attend casinos on occasion. Mr. Toma's family and the police are concerned for his safety and well-being.

Case reference: 2012020647.CaseDesc:
Ricky Riopel was reported missing in August 2010 by family members who had not seen or heard from him since December 2008. It was later established that Mr. Riopel had been in Moose Jaw at a health care facility in October 2009.

Case reference: 2018054173.CaseDesc: On September 23, 2018, at approximately 11:00am, Melvin Hillier was last seen at his home in Torbay, Newfoundland. Mr. Hillier had advised his family that he was going for a drive. Melvin’s blue pick-up truck was later located abandoned on the MV Legionnaire (one of the ferries that operates between Portugal Cove-St. Phillips and Bell Island, Newfoundland). Case reference: 2008003999.CaseDesc: Bernard Champagne was last seen on July 10, 1997.  He was a bachelor and lived alone for 40 years in a cabin with no running water or electricity, located behind the Rodrigue residence. Mr. Rodrigue contacted the police and a search by canine, helicopter, and E.R.T. was conducted but proved unsuccessful in locating Mr. Champagne.

Case reference: 2012020089.CaseDesc: Michel Guy Favreau lived by himself in Nipawin, Saskatchewan and was in good physical health at the time of his disappearance. Mr. Favreau suffered from depression and was on medication for that illness. The last time anyone spoke to or saw Mr. Favreau was between September 22nd and September 25th, 2011. On October 4th, 2011 his vehicle, a 1998 green Chrysler Intrepid, was observed abandoned at Carrol's Cove camp ground near Nipawin. The vehicle was locked, the keys were in the ignition and Mr. Favreau's wallet was inside. Several searches including ground, water, and air, conducted in hopes of locating him were unsuccessful.

Case reference: 2008005999.CaseDesc: On September 8, 1978, Brian McLean and his co-worker, Russell Thomas, were commercial fishing at their camp on MacDowell Lake, near MacDowell Lake First Nation Territory. Mr. Thomas advised that they left in separate boats to lift nets. He went to the west side of the lake and pulled four nets, then to the east side of the lake and lifted two more nets. He then realized that Mr. McLean was not there. Mr. Thomas headed back towards the camp and found Mr. McLean’s boat washed up against the shore approximately three or four hundred metres from the camp. The motor was in forward gear with the throttle off, and the paddle was missing from the boat. MacDowell Lake is 90 "air miles" north of Red Lake, and is accessible only by air. The area was searched, and the lake was dragged, but Brian McLean has not been found.

PersonsData.Name: MCLEAN, Brian Douglas

Case reference: 2005006299.CaseDesc:
On June 16 1977, the body of a male was recovered from the Niagara River at the Canadian Niagara Power House above the Niagara Falls. 
His post-mortem weight was recorded as being between 200-210 lbs and his length was measured at 5'8", however, these measurements may not represent his actual living weight and height due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy.
His appendix is present and he may have suffered from high blood pressure, diabetes and/or alcoholism. He may have also suffered from pancreatitis in the past. He is thought to have been in the water for approximately 1 to 2 months.

Case reference: 2014006470.CaseDesc: On June 4, 2001, Shahzad Ahmed was seen for the last time at his residence in Toronto, Ontario. Shahzad last contacted his mother by telephone to tell her that he had been fired from his job. During the course of their conversation, his mother had told him to return home to her apartment in Toronto, but he never arrived. The next telephone call that Shahzad’s mother received was from the Islamabad police in Pakistan, who had informed her that Shahzad’s luggage had been found unclaimed on the airport luggage carousel.

Case reference: 2013000103.CaseDesc: On September 20, 1969,  three commercial fishermen sold their catch, purchased groceries and departed Jackpine Island for Brochet via Reindeer Lake. Mr. Bighetty left in his own canoe and was ahead of two other men who were also travelling by canoe. The second canoe later had mechanical problems and had to stop on an island. The two men indicated that they had heard the other canoe and figured it was Mr. Bighetty coming back to look for them. However, they never saw him again. Mr. Bighetty's canoe was located in the lake in a vertical position 9.6 kilometers south of Brochet. It is presumed he drowned and no foul play is suspected in this matter.

Case reference: 2005001199.CaseDesc: On May 3, 1975, the remains of a female were found in the Nation River near a bridge crossing Highway 417 in Casselman, Ontario. She has dyed reddish blonde hair that was naturally dark brown. Her finger and toe nails had red nail polish on them. She may have been a smoker. The cause of death was strangulation. A piece of television coaxial cable was found around her neck. A curtain rod runner (plastic wheel) was found in her left armpit. Her hands and feet were tied with men's neckties, one of which is called "The Canadian Tie". Her remains may have been in the water for some days to some months.

Case reference: 2014002145.CaseDesc: On September 13, 1975, Mr. Garson with his father, brother and a friend set out for Moose Lake to hunt. On September 14, other hunters found gas cans, and a thermos with the name of Garson on it. These hunters reported their findings to police.  A search was initiated and police found a boat submerged upright on the bottom of the lake. The depth of the lake around the boat was only 8 to 10 feet deep. It appeared to Police that the men encountered extremely rough water while crossing Moose Lake. The motors were both found to be in forward gear. There was no floatation gear in the boat and it was heavily loaded with camping and hunting equipment. All of the bodies were recovered with the exception of M. Garson. It is presumed Mr. Garson drowned.

PersonsData.Name: GARSON, William Wesley

Case reference: 2013000010.CaseDesc: On December 3rd 1996, family members of Jaime Wyatt made a report to the St-John's RCMP that he had not been seen since November 12th, 1996. Mr. Wyatt, a resident of Newfoundland, left the province in September 1996 to seek employment in Nova Scotia. The investigation revealed that Jaime Wyatt had been staying at the Twin Elms Motel on Inglis Street in Halifax and he was last seen there on November 16th, 1996. His motel room was paid in full until the 17th of November 1996. On the evening of November 16th, 1996, Mr. Wyatt informed the staff at the Twin Elms that someone was going to be picking him up to go out to a dinner party and other functions that evening. Mr. Wyatt was never heard from or seen since that day. Foul play is suspected.

Case reference: 2005005699.CaseDesc: On June 22, 1991, the body of an unidentified man was recovered from the Niagara River between Horseshoe Falls and the "Maid of the Mist" boat docks. His post-mortem weight was recorded as being 113 lbs, however this measurement may not represent his actual living weight due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy. He had signs of having suffered an acute or chronic right lung infection. He is estimated to have been dead for several months. Biogeographic Ancestry testing predicts this unidentified male is either of European ancestry, or South Asian ancestry, or mixed European and South Asian ancestry.

Case reference: 2008016999.CaseDesc: Meryl Newcombe and George Weeden were last seen and reported missing to the White River OPP on October 29, 1959. The two men had been at a lodge operated by Mr. Newcombe at Mile 107 of the CPR line, west of Chapleau, Ontario. Mr. Weeden and Mr. Newcombe had planned a hunting trip and both were last seen between mile marker 106 and 107 of the CPR line southeast of White River and west of Chapleau. A large-scale search was conducted at the time, and again in the following spring (1960).  The search failed to locate the two men, and to date, they have not been located. Mr. Weeden exact date of birth is not known, but his year of birth is understood to be 1896 or 1897.

Case reference: 2005006599.CaseDesc:
On September 18, 1978, the body of an unidentified man was found in the Toronto Harbour of Lake Ontario. His post-mortem weight was 163lbs and his length was measured at 5'10", however, these measurements may not represent his actual living weight and height due to post-mortem changes noted at autopsy.
Staining on his teeth suggest that he may have been a smoker. It is estimated that he had been in the water for several weeks.

Case reference: 2005001799.CaseDesc: On June 1, 1975, the body of an older adult female was located on the west bank of the Niagara River, in the town of Niagara-on-the-Lake. She is believed to be the same person who was witnessed jumping into the Horseshoe Falls on February 17, 1975. She is thought to be 40 plus years, short and heavy-set, with brown hair. She suffered from lung disease and had severe arthritis of her lumbar spine, which may have been painful. When witnessed going over the Falls, she was wearing a long overcoat, possibly grey, and carrying a green umbrella. There is no confirmation that the jumper and the deceased are the same person, however the general descriptions are in agreement. The condition of her remains suggest that she had been in the water for weeks to months.

Case reference: 2014001425.CaseDesc: On August 3rd, 1986, RCMP received a report of a missing person. The manager of Sickle Lake Lodge called advising Mr. Hrynick went missing in the early morning hours. Mr. Hrynick was with friends during the evening before and into the early morning. According to them, Mr. Hrynick had been very quiet over the couple days leading up to his disappearance. The evening of his disappearance, Mr. Hrynick was described as intoxicated. At one point, witnesses observed him stumbling on his way out the door of the cabin. The other men went out to search for Mr. Hrynick about 15 minutes later. They could hear a boat but could not see Mr. Hrynick. The empty boat was located the following day. An extensive land and water search failed to locate Mr. Hrynick. There was no indication that Mr. Hrynick found his way to the shore and he has not been seen since.

Case reference: 2014005450.CaseDesc: On June 6, 1979 James Gordon Nevin departed from his residence in Amherstburg, Ontario heading west for a 2 week vacation with the intention of visiting relatives. Mr. Nevin had a grandson in Winnipeg, Manitoba and a son in Prince George, British Columbia. Neither relative had prior notification Mr. Nevin's intentions to visit.   On June 14, 1979 the RCMP responded to a call and James Nevin's vehicle, a 1974 white/maroon Dodge Coronet, was located in a ditch between Rocanville, Saskatchewan and St. Lazare, Manitoba. Inquiries reveal the vehicle was at this location since June 8, 1979.   Mr. Nevin has never been seen again and likely went missing between 1:30 pm and 3:00 pm on June 8, 1979. Extensive searches were conducted by land and air all with negative results. James Gordon Nevin was never seen again. Foul play cannot be ruled out.

PersonsData.Name: NEVIN, James Gordon

Case reference: 2012003399.CaseDesc: Gregory Porter, 26, was last seen on October 5, 1984, when he was honourably discharged from the army at the Canadian Forces Base in Wainwright, Alberta. He had told people that he was going to British Columbia to drive a taxi. He was in good health both physically and mentally. The initial investigation revealed that Mr. Porter cashed a bank draft for $2400 on October 9, 1984, at a Royal Bank in Edmonton, Alberta. His whereabouts remain unknown.

Case reference: 2014004419.CaseDesc: Holly Painter was initially reported as a missing person on June 26, 1995. On that evening, two friends of Holly's reported that they were at her residence when an argument broke out between Holly and one of the friends. They said that Holly assaulted that friend; the other friend then took Holly from the residence. All 3 of them left in the second friend's vehicle, with him driving. He reported that he intended to take Holly to her parents' residence, however, while making a left turn at an intersection, she jumped out of the vehicle and ran off.

Case reference: 2009004799.CaseDesc: Neil McDougall left Three-Way Demolition in Durham on Friday, October 11, 1985 with a co-worker and went home. He had an argument with his wife and the friend left. After supper Mr. McDougall went to Ayton, to the Commercial Hotel. He left the hotel with someone else and they met up elsewhere with the co-worker.  Mr. McDougall returned to the hotel and left at closing time, between 1:30 – 1:40 am. He was last reported leaving a residence on Edmund Street, Ayton at 2 a.m. October 12, 1985. His pickup truck was discovered near Ayton later that day. The ashtray was filled with different brands of cigarette butts. He has been described as meticulous, habitual, responsible and hardworking. When he went missing, Neil was planning to adopt his wife's children. Foul play is suspected. Mr. McDougall was declared legally dead in 1996.

PersonsData.Name: MCDOUGALL, Neil James

Case reference: 2014004911.CaseDesc: On July 3, 1974, Mr. Harper, his wife and their young child were out on the lake duck hunting and fishing. At one point in the day, the party stopped on shore to eat. During this stop, they noticed a storm coming in. By the time they left there were already waves forming as they started out across the lake. The wind increased and the waves were so strong that they would almost cause the vessel to flip over. The boat filled with water and a wave took Mr. Harper out of the boat. His wife and child drifted in the boat until they reached shore and were later rescued. No foul play is suspected in this matter and it is presumed Mr. Harper drowned.

PersonsData.Name: HARPER, Ellice

Case reference: 2014001572.CaseDesc: On July 19, 1970, Arthur Stephens left his home in Gimli, Manitoba. He had planned to go fishing in the Whiteshell Provincial Park. Arthur told his wife that he would return on July 21, 1970. He further advised her that if he was going to stay any longer, he would call her to let her know. By July 22, 1970, Arthur had not returned home and his wife hadn't received a phone call. She reported him missing to police that day. On August 1, 1970, Arthur's vehicle was located near Falcon Beach.  Extensive ground, lake and air searches were done of the area. All efforts to locate him failed to uncover any further leads. Arthur Stephens whereabouts remain unknown.

PersonsData.Name: STEPHENS, Arthur Clifford

Case reference: 2006028499.CaseDesc: On August 3, 1968, at approximately 4:30 p.m., Robert James Brown was last seen walking  from the Nazarene Camp to his home in the Village of Wilfred, Ontario. The Nazarene Camp was a Christian camp near Pefferlaw, where Robert's mother worked as a volunteer.  He never arrived home and was reported missing to the Georgina Township Police Service. There were reports that a person matching Robert's description was seen in the vicinity of Georgina Beach around the time that Robert was last seen. Numerous land and water searches failed to locate Robert.

Case reference: 2014006426.CaseDesc: Sara Coates was last seen in the Stanley Park area in Calgary, Alberta. Ms. Coates was leading a nomadic lifestyle, living out of her van with her dog and 3 cats, travelling around Alberta and BC. Ms. Coates’ van was located October 22, 2013, in a secluded area of Morley, Alberta. It appeared to have been there for some time. Police investigations regarding Ms. Coates’ whereabouts are ongoing.

Case reference: 2014002034.CaseDesc: In 1968, Christina Littlejohn was last seen on the Roseau River First Nation reserve in Manitoba. Further investigations by the RCMP revealed that Christina had been murdered by her common law partner. In 2002, the RCMP’s Cold Case Unit laid murder charges against her common law partner, however he passed away before the trial commenced. To date Christina’s remains have not been located.

Case reference: 2011005499.CaseDesc: Lukas was last seen on October 3, 2011, heading into the bushes behind Chomista Trailer park. His duffle bag was located in the bushes with his personal property on October 7, 2011. He was en route to his sister's place, but never arrived. Lukas has ties to Winnipeg and Calgary.

Case reference: 2010005899.CaseDesc: Mark Edmonson disappeared from his residence in Stoney Creek on October 3, 1999. Mr. Edmonson has not returned or contacted his family members since that time and both his family and Police are concerned for his well being. Mr. Edmonson is developmentally challenged. It is believed that Mr. Edmonson left home without taking any money or personal identification. Extensive police searches have failed to determine his whereabouts.

Case reference: 2006022699.CaseDesc: Nick Hibbart was prospecting when he was last seen by police at his camp on Gravel River on June 8, 1988. Police returned to the area on July 25, 1988, and found that the camp was burned to the ground. There was no sign of Mr. Hibbart and investigations have failed to determine his whereabouts.
